reviews.review: Amazing sumo tournament!. Having never seen sumo live before, I had no idea what to expect. I thought I'd be bored after an hour. Not so! Sumo matches are short but very exciting to watch, and the crowd was great and supportive of their favorites. We paid about $90 for two people, but this is for mid-tier, all-day seats so I don't consider it expensive. I do recommend buying tickets on your own in advance, rather than going through some tour agency, because the stadium is really easy to get to and fun enough without a tour guide (and the tour guide's price markup!). I recommend getting chankonabe for lunch or dinner nearby--if you do you won't need to eat again for quite a while!
Sumo tournament, absolute highlight. Came here for a sumo tournament, one of the coolest things to do in japan. Traditional japanese culture and exciting combat all baked into one!

Great Tokyo spectacle with Sakai. A great event particularly on a rainy day if in Tokyo. The seating is very well organised and drinks and food are delivered to your matt seating area. Great thing to experience with friends colleagues and enjoy a beer. The wrestling is fluid and constant change and really good experience. Everyone very welcoming and friendly neighbours sharing in the atmosphere.

One of the most unique and captivating sporting events I've been to. We lucked into tickets to see a day of the September sumo basho (tournament) while in Tokyo for vacation, through the friend of a friend who couldn't use her tickets. The pageantry is so medieval it's like imagine if jousting on horseback had remained a spectator sport unbroken in tradition since the days of Henry the VIIIth. Sumo is also much more exciting live than via Youtube. The crowd is very into it, cheering and clapping at even the good moves during the pre-fight posturing that goes on. To Western eyes the pre-fight seems almost silly, like pro wrestlers pumping up the crowd, but it's actually the first round of the fight in a lot of ways, and live that's much more obvious than on video. Seeing an afternoon of sumo is a lot like watching an afternoon of baseball. There's a lot of sitting around chatting and eating (and just like in baseball, the better seats have waiter service, while the rest of us go to concession stands) punctuated by exciting action at measured intervals. There are people who find baseball boring and so I'm sure there are some who would find sumo boring, too, but to anyone who knows a little about the martial arts and who generally likes spectator sports, sumo live is a rewarding experience. The atmosphere is very genial and family-oriented, too, again reminding me of American baseball. ABOUT THE VENUE: There is a large trophy case with fascinating artifacts from sumo history in it, and on tournament days there are souvenir vendors, mascots to take photos with, etc. The "box seats" are four person platforms with cushions--you remove your shoes and sit crosslegged or lounge around. The upper deck appears to have regular stadium-style seats which might be better for westerners who aren't comfortable sitting on the floor.

One to the best sporting events I've been to. First day in Tokyo on an eight day stay with the family. Bit worried that the a sumo tournament may not hold the attention of my two daughters and wife for the afternoon but was completely wrong.Had four box seats - you are in a a box with four cushions surrounded by couples, families, business men and friends. People are here for a great afternoon and you can feel it in the it air. We were there on the Friday before the Sunday final and things wee beginning to heat up.Like any big sporting event it's about the crowd, some drinks /food and the battle. As a newbie to this I would arrive around 3, get settled, drinks/food, meet the neighbours and prepare for the final session.Sumo is as much about the theatre as it is the bouts. If you can get hold of a ticket then go - it is something you will remember forever.The final bout was massively exciting and finished with everyone frisbeeing their cushions into the ring while cheering, chanting and clapping. If it can hold the attention of two girls 11/12 on the back of a 10 her flight it's got to be good.

Japanese national sport. If you are in Tokyo for the Sumo wrestling tournament it is worth going to watch .Tickets can be ordered in advance or bought on the day.The arena is huge. the wrestling goes on all day, best to visit for the final bouts as you get to see the better wrestlers - 3/6pm.Drinks , toilets, food and gift shops on each seating level.To appreciate the kills it might be best to mug up on the rules and etiquette of Sumo wrestling before you visit. Bouts can be over in 3 seconds but the pre bout rituals are interesting to watch.

Sumo tournament. We had a great time at the sumo tournament. We managed to get tickets online ahead of time (we went on a Friday night, and it was sold out when we got there). When we got the tickets, they recommended either buying an entire box of 4 seats, or 2 regular seats. The box seats are mats on the floor, and once we got there we could see why they'd recommended buying all 4 seats; they're small and nothing in the way of back support. If you're not used to sitting on the floor for long periods of time and/or you have back issues or anything like that, you might want to consider the seats a level up. They're very comfortable and afford a great view of everything that's going on.The tournament is interesting, but unless you're really into Sumo, don't worry about showing up until around 5pm. The tournament starts at like 8am, but the good bouts are all later. The entrances of the 2 main groups are worth seeing, and you want to stay to the bow ceremony at the end. Getting out is a little crazy, so my suggestion is either wait til the crowd disperses a bit, and maybe try to find a place nearby to hang out for an hour, as the trains were packed solid (but what's Tokyo without a sardine-tight train ride, right?).

Sensational sumo. We were fortunate enough to be in Tokyo when the sumo tournament was on so it was a bit of a must do. I purchased tickets online on the day they became available so the good seats sell quickly. We sat in the boxed area with four cushions on the floor. This was squishy as my son and husband are over six foot tall but we figured it would be an authentic experience. We were there for around five hours so managed to make it work.I collected tickets at the venue - there are signs at kiosks that say "will call" which is terminology used on online documentation. You will need credit card number of card used to purchase to redeem tickets. There are plenty of food options at stadium and surrounds and a McDonald's across the road. I would highly recommend a sumo experience as it gives you a great insight to the tradition and sport.

Greatly entertaining!. Purchased tickets about two months before our trip and attended the sumo tournament. We went the second to last day (14th day, Saturday) of the September tournament. We arrived about 2 pm which was a good time to get there. They were wrapping up a session and many people started to arrive about 2:30. I would highly recommend getting the radio to listen to while you are there. They start renting them out at 2:30 and its $32 but you get $30 back when you return it. The English commentators were good and helped us follow what was going on.There are about 20 matches in the final session, going from about 4-6 pm. We followed along the bout sheet that showed the wrestlers with their record for the tournament. There were some excellent matches and one guy was 13-0 and he clinched the tournament win with a victory during this session. The crowd went crazy! The pre match warming up, etc is worth the price of admission. The ceremonies and rituals really aren't that long. Very cool venue and glad we went!

Sumo was unforgettable. If you're in Tokyo during September when the sumo tournament is on, you really must try and get tickets. We are by no means sumo fans, but it's one of those traditional, authentic Japanese activities that you can't afford to miss.The rules are relatively easy to pick up, and the atmosphere is fantastic - especially later on once the really good wrestlers start coming out. We sat next to a Japanese chap who shared his food with us, tried to talk to us about the matches, and encouraged us to lob our cushions once the last match was over!We also got a hand-drawn sumo picture which was signed in Japanese by the artist. Superb.

Awesome!. Book at least a month in advance. Sumo is awesome. The only similar experience I have is a day tennis tournament in Wimbledon. If you are in September in Tokyo go for it! Sumo is only a few weeks a year. Tokyo in September, Nagoya in July, check for Osaka and another place (can't remember).At the Ryogoku Kokugikan in Tokyo a 4 persons box is J¥38,000 (about £70 per person). It is more expensive to get nearer the ring. Amazing spectacle. The price is for a "box" - an enclosed square with four low metallic bars and four thin cushions. There is a beer bottle opener attached to the rail. People take big bags of food - bento boxes on sale inside the venue. The sumo wrestling started in the morning with the novice rank, the top levels were after 2pm and it ended at 6pm.Quite empty until the big guns arrive. Cross legs sitting on the floor was hard work. Two in a box is comfortable, three a squeeze, four is like battling for elbow space on an economy flight, then add the legs! If four can stay in meditative lotus position that's fine, otherwise take turns to walk around, that's okey. Sumo wrestlers' special soup (Chanko) available downstairs, or taste the Chanko later at a restaurant (the Chanko Kirishina) belonging to a retired Sumo champion. After a day on the floor, you might want chairs to sit on, so head for the Chanko Kirishina's fourth floor (lift) and forget the ground floor tatami.

Incredible Sumo experience. One of the most unique and special experiences of our visit to Japan was watching a sumo tournament here.We had tickets for the whole day but arrived in the afternoon as the good matches are supposed to start, our seats were probably a bit further away than we would have liked but the really good seats are all mats to kneel on rather than seated.We didn't really have any idea what was happening with the actual matches or who was fighting but it was spectacular to see such athletes competing so hard for the fights.The arena was incredible and the culture surround the matches was fascinating to watch, I would definitely recommend anyone coming to Tokyo to try and see a tournament.

Sumo tournament. A fantastic afternoon watching sumo wrestling! I had wanted to watch sumo live since seeing it on the TV a long time ago and it did not disappoint.If you are in town when a tournament is on do not miss it

Sumo sensation. The sumo tournament is on but you don't have a ticket. What do you do? Go anyway. Tip: hang outside the stadium at the food trucks and souvenir stores that are set up near side entrance. While fans queue up to get in, you have scored a top spot where the sumo big boys enter and leave. And they are happy to pose for photos. We snacked, enjoyed beer in the sun, watched matches on the food truck's big TV and had some sumo fun. When the tournament is not on you can visit a sumo museum. Next time. This was such a great experience.

really a Japan experience!. book your tickets early online. as on the morning of the event, the queue stretches till almost the JR station. door open at 8am sharp. seats werent fill up then. you are allowed re entry once at south exit. so u have to exit and reenter south exit. you can take upclose photos and maybe with them, outside on the left side.. near entrance 4-6. really good deal watching them. there are food stalls and souvenir shops at level 1. level 1 need ticket as it is the more expensive seats. nonetheless a good experience. MUST visit if you are in Tokyo. do check out their website for the schedule. paid close to 100+ SGD for one pax. worth the $.

Sumo expirience in Tokyo. If you are in Tokyo during the sumo tournament, do not miss it. The tournament takes place in the Ryogoku Kokugikan (national sumo arena) which is placed in the part of Tokyo called Ryogoku. The arena is placed yust infront of the railway station, if you come with JR, if you come by subway it will take you cca 5 min. walk from the subway station Ryogoku. It is a whole day event, although the main competition starts after 15h.Do not miss the chanko nabe (stew for sumo wrestlers) which is served in the banquet hall in the basement of the arena( from 12h-16h, for 300 Y). The daily ticket allows you one reenty, so it is allowed to go out once. You can stroll through Ryogoku and try to have lunch in one of the numerous small restaurants in the tiny streets across the railway station. Tickets should be booked well in advance.All in all this a unique expirience for the Tokyo visitors which I strongly recommend.

Must check out, if in season. Sumo competitions happens for 15 days on the odd months in Japan and in different cities during the months. It's very much part of the Shinto culture.Our guide from viator was good and she explained in details about the different aspects of the match.It was very entertaining to watch the competition.I've been to Japan many times and this is one of the more memorable events, since sumo competition is very much part of the Japanese culture, although this sport is no longer fashionable with the young.The stadium was still fairly crowded for Day 2 and I'd imagine that it would get increasingly crowded and rowdy-fun was the competition draws towards the end.Tickets weren't cheap, but it's worth the experience :) You won't see this else where, but shopping can be done almost anywhere.
Best day we have had. If you are in Tokyo when tournament is on do not pass up the opportunity to see this. Amazing experience.

Timed it right!. Couldn't believe our luck when we realised we had timed our Tokyo dates with the September Sumo tournament. Tickets weren't cheap but you have to do this if you can. The only reason this didn't get 5 stars is due to the uncomfortable seating arrangements. Boxes are marked out on the floor for 4 people to sit on cushions but they really only fit 2. Your back gets a knock on the brass bars around the box! Superb event though, very ceremonial. Highly recommend the radio rental (cheap) if you have never been before.

Highlight of my trip to Tokyo! . I was lucky enough to get a ticket for the Autumn Basho and it was the best thing I did in Tokyo. Tickets were easy to buy and pick up in English on the Oosumo website. It is really easy to see from anywhere in the stadium and typically there are people coming and going all day so once you're in you can sit in another free seat until it's occupier comes if you want. Food and drink is available inside but the queues can be really long during breaks between bouts. You can bring it in from the convenience store even though the sign says otherwise! I found the ritual and ceremony really interesting and the fight was exciting. I was lucky to be there when the best wrestlers were fighting. They walk around outside and you can talk to them and get pictures even though they are very famous in Japan, so if you didn't manage to score a ticket it's still nice to visit during championships and visit the Tokyo-Edo Museum as well. I'd love to watch sumo again next time in Tokyo.

National sumo wrestling stadium. This stadium is for Sumo tournaments in January, March and September. The tournaments are hold in only two weeks. If you want to watch games, you should check schedule before planning your stay in Tokyo.Inside of the stadium, there are flat spaces on the 1st floor, and there are chair seats on 2nd floor. I highly recommend to take your seats on 2nd floor, because to sit at flat spaces would be very difficult.Usually tickets will sell out before tournaments. I recommend you to get tickets through travel agencies. A little bit more expensive, but you will definitely be able to get tickets.

The nobility of the sport!. Our intention was only to visit take a look at a few matches, but the atmosphere and following was so addictive, that we were there all day. Local came to the see matches with the packed lunches and on the upper floor were also stalls where food was able to buy. Local beer was sold directly to the backpack and sellers circulate throughout the stadium. You can sit on anywhere, but when the place holder will be the site then you will have to move. We had good luck when there was almost a full-time upstairs in the front row. Tickets should be really good time to book if you want to sit downstairs in the stadium.Top atmosphere, a great place for entertaining and definitely worth visiting place!

An unique sport. I was very excited to watch matches between the sumo. It is not like any other kind of fighting, mostly wrestling but in a very unique way. My luck was so big that I could have the signature of a high grade summon for my boy. All members in my family had so much fun here. Absolutely an awesome experience for anyone visiting Tokyo.

So fun!. Lots of fun! Such an experience! We wish we rented the English audio players though. We were seating next to another family from Canada, same province even. Small world. Was interesting to see that not all the wrestlers were Japanese. Was fun to people watch as well. Spied some women in kimono and a small brawl broke out in the crowd as well. We went around 2pm so we wouldn't miss the entrance ceremony of the higher ranked sumo's. I read that they close the doors at this time so if you were late you'd miss the ceremony. But when I looked around there were still people coming and going.

Unbelievable, Unforgettable Experience. Absolutely the highlight of our trip. We spent the better part of a day hanging out here watching the sumo. From the low-grade wrestlers to the top-grade, they were all equally impressive. Of course, as you get to the high grade wrestlers the ceremony becomes bigger and the fans get louder. You can't help but be caught up in it all and start cheering on your favourites.There is food and drinks here, as well as clean bathrooms - so you can really get comfy and get to know the sport.

Fantastic experience . We were going to the Edo Museum next door and only ended up here as we saw lots of sumo wrestlers wandering around. It turned out it was the national championships so we bought two cheap tickets (to sit on the back row). After our museum visit and lunch in a nearby noodle bar, during which a sumo sat next to me (I nearly exploded with excitement!), we stood outside for a while to watch the wrestlers coming in. We then took our seats and, despite being so high up, we had a good view. There are good facilities in the stadium and, like all of Japan, it's immaculate. Watching the wrestling was one of the highlights of our trip to this fab country.

Must See While in Japan. If there's a competition while you are in Tokyo, you should definitely try to get tickets. We were lucky to be in Tokyo while a major competition was being held. We did not purchase tickets in advance but was able to get cheap day-of tickets. Regular tickets range from $3800 Yen up and usually sell out fast. Discounted tickets are available day of the match and are around $2100 Yen. Seat selection is not an option for discounted tickets as they are only available when seats are not sold. Make sure you go early if you are planning to get discounted tickets. Sumo matches begin around 9am with major matches starting mid-afternoon. The ticket allows for same day in/out privileges. We noticed that people brought food in the stadium and no one seemed to mine. They have food on site as well if you do not have time to go out to buy your own. We got to the arena around 2pm and was able to catch a glimpse of some of the sumo wrestler walking into the arena. Our discounted tickets were for seats at the highest section of the stadium but we were still able to see pretty well. It was great to watch the competition with locals and tourist alike. We really enjoyed the experience and will definitely make it a point to catch another competition the next time we are in Japan.
An experience. This place is really nice and let you the chance to vibrate for these big boys.I went to a retirement ceremony, fantastic.The bentos served are great. You see from any seats.

Fantastic experience. Great if you can attend a sumo tournament. We were lucky because there was a retirement event with many wrestlers challenging each other in honor of the retiree. They sang, his sponsors cut his hair and much more!

A not to missed experience. Sumo is Japan's national sport and is a sport that may baffle foreigners but it is one of my favourite Japanese experiences. 3 times a year tournaments are held here and if you are in Tokyo during those times make sure you go. You can buy tickets in advance but they do sell out quickly or you can go for the cheapest option with the furthest away seats which is to buy tickets on the day. There are 300 odd tickets that they sell from 8am each morning of the tournament for general seating in the back row, make sure you arrive much earlier then this though as they do sell out of these tickets quickly. The sumo itself goes the whole day but the best sumo's start from about 2pm. Eat Chunko, it's a sumo staple diet food to bulk up. You can also get away with bringing food and drink in usually despite the signs saying otherwise. It is an amazing atmosphere with so much ritual so do a little bit of research before and it will be an amazing experience. During the rest of the year you can visit the sumo museum for free.

Sumo is Japan's National Sport. Great atmosphere. I truly enjoyed the National Sumo Tournament at Ryogoku Kokugikan. The atmosphere was electric in the sold out arena. If you are in Tokyo during the National Tournament ...do not miss the opportunity to see real Sumo.

Very entertaining! . The stadium was so big and clean. The toilets were accesible too, it was very clean as expected. Drinking fountains were near the entrance. There were also shops where you can buy souvenir and food items. Watching sumo for the first time was a very nice experience and worth every penny.

Unique experience. Incredible. First thing to say is we got lucky, we planned and trip to Tokyo and it so happened the September Tournament was happening at that time. So my first piece of advice is that depending on how flexible you are, check the tournament dates and plan your trip around that.The arena is quite impressive from the outside, but once you get inside it is stunning. Sumo is one of the most unique things I have experienced in my life. So different to any sport of cultural activity I know or have seen before. I would highly recommend. The seats are very comfortable and the ticket is valid all day. We got the second cheapest for I believe about 20/25 pounds. We still had a good view. We showed up around 2.30pm before the higher league started, and a lovely (and well deserved) nap and then enjoyed the show. The lights in the stadium are just right as well, not too bright not too dark. Not speaking english didn't matter although I think to have a better experience you might want to brush up on Sumo wrestling rules. But by observing we understood most of it after a couple fights.All in all a highlight of our trip. Make sure you book in advance. I would also recommend enjoying a bento box while you are there to take the cultural experience a bit further. Unique and amazing.

Sumo tournament . One of the highlights of our trip to Japan. I would definitely recommend going if you are in Tokyo during one of the tournaments. We went early and stood in line and got day of general admission tickets as tournaments sell out weeks in advance. These tickets go on sale every morning at the stadium at 8am. Only 350 tickets are sold each day and when you arrive you are given a number 1-350 which allows you to stand in line to buy a tix. We got there around 7:20AM and just barely made the cutoff. Matches start at 9 but the good wrestlers don't wrestle until after 2pm so we actually went and did other sights in the morning and came back to the stadium at 2 and stayed til the end. Once in the stadium the general admission seats are the very highest row seats but no one seems to check tickets and there were blocks of empty seats so we sat very low and if anyone did come we just moved to another area.

Was hooked on Sumo Wrestling by the end of the day. Sumo wrestlers are well and truly worshipped in Japan, so I was very happy when we arrived having prebooked tickets through the english website before we left.I was also very surprised to see some of the wrestlers walking in just off the street! Despite the language barrier, two I asked for a photo with were happy to oblige.The stadium itself is incredible to arrive in, there's not a bad seat in the house so don't worry too much about paying for the close tickets, we were right up the back but had a great view and I would guess that is the case for most of the stadium.We turned up mid afternoon, probably around 2:30 because we were told our tickets had to be collected by 3.This ensured we saw much of the 'reserve grade' bouts, plus the top fighters. You're given a sheet with the day's match ups + each fighter's tournament results, which is handy as it gives you an idea of who the stronger fighters are, and who's not going as well.Great to see how passionate the crowd was about some of the wrestlers. The whole spectacle was just amazing and great fun.

Great Thrilling Expereince!!. If you are in Tokyo between 10-24th May. Do not miss the opportunity to see the great Sumo wrestling. Please go around 2:30 or 3 PM and stay till end which is at around 6. It would be a thrilling expereince to learn about this great national game of Japan and see the Sumos in action. We booked our tours through Viator and they were very peofessional about the whole thing. Its extremely difficult to get tickets on your own even when I tried the day tickets started selling. But if you can buy tickets on your own, you dont need to book a tour and it will save you a lot of money. But in any case, do not miss this while in Tokyo.

Pricey, but unforgettable experience. If you can get tickets, I recommend sitting on the South side so you get the best view, but definitely go for chairs as unless you're used to hours of kneeling,you won't cope! Hire a radio to get the English commentary, and read up on the rules online to get the most out of the day. Beware, the food inside is expensive - bring your own picnic (discreetly).

Brilliant. I went to watch a day of sumo wrestling during the May Festival and it has to be one of my favourite travelling experiences.The ritual around the sumo wrestling is gripping and it is very watchable, even if you have never watched the sport before. The arena itself is very impressive. There is a variety of food and drink available just outside the arena, including the high protein dish that sumo wrestlers eat to bulk up. I would say the entire venue has a good view of the arena. You can also very easily bump into the sumo wrestlers when you walk around the outside of the arena.Tip: the high profile sumo wrestlers are on much later in the day. The second tier wrestlers enter early afternoon, and the top tier wrestlers enter mid-to late-afternoon.

Sumo secrets unlocked. By now you have already ready that this is a fantastic, quintessentially Japanese experience that I'd highly recommend to first-timers in Tokyo. So let's get to what you want to know..how do I get tickets!? Ok there are several ways to get to see the tournament.1- prepay for your tickets online before you leave for your trip. You can find sumo tickets online , I use the official sumo association website to buy my tickets. But you can find 3rd party retailers too. Remember there is a date change when you fly in to japan. So be sure to plan with that date change in mind.2- family mart conveniance store has events tickets which you can by at the store. You will need to read Japanese or have someone hellp you navigate the kiosk screen to get your tickets.3- Day of tickets, you will need to go early to the the ticket booth at the arena and buy open general seating tickets. these tickets are very limited less then 200 for regular day match. I doubt you would be able to get open seating for,the final,day but it's still,worth a try. I recommend you get there no later that 0530-6am. Box office opens at 7. You will see the line when you get there. 4- Craigslist...yes you can find people,selling there tickets on craigslist. Obviously this would be a last resort and buyer beware. The Japanese culture really frowns upon scalping tickets. But you can find scalpers but it won't be like in the states where they are openly selling tickets. You may run across a guy usually a foreigner whispering something about tickets. Things to keep in mind. If you buy a box seat, it's is made to seat for people...Japanese people... The box is roughly 4x5 you will be seated on the floor. It can be uncomfortable if your aren't flexible. Squeezing 4 Americans will be a challenge but who cares have fun!English-language commentary is available even for the higher-level matches. Once your are in the arena look for,the radio rental table. Don't be put off at the price 3200 yen, it's a deposit. You will get 3000 yen back when you return to the radio to them. For 200 yen it's well worth listening to the English commentary and making the match enjoyable.When to go. Ok so the matches start at 8 am. Unless you are a die hard fan or your son is a junior light weight wrestler your probably can wait to go later in the day. The match starts off with the lowest of,the low wrestling. The neat part about it is that even the grand champion started off that way. I recommend going about 2 pm. You can wonder the arena buy your sumo souvenirs grab a bite to eat and settle,in your seat. The big boys start to arrive about 3 pm and they start the ring ceremony for the paying ranks about 345pm. This is what you came for! Where ever you are seated you will notice a lot of open seating. You will be tempted to jump in another seat or to,something closer . You can take a chance an try and move to get a better view just be ready to move when you see that guy looking for,his seat and your are in it. Simple apologize and smile. Remember the Japanese are very by the rules culture and it may be frowned upon not to be in your assigned seat, but you can always drop the foreigner card and play dumb, you will be forgiven.Picture taking - yes take pictures snap away! Flash and all! The arena will be full of photo ops. You will see full,figure cut outs of the top,wrestlers around which can be a fun picture. You will want to take a picture of the wrestler themselves. The best time to do this is when you see the wrestlers leaving for the day outside the arena.You will find that even the top ranked wrestlers are very gracious and are usually happy to pose with you for a photo. Just asked politely and be sure to thank them for their time. Don't be turned off by a wrestler saying no or ignoring you. He probably lost his match and is is no mood for pictures. The Lower ranking wrestlers will be walking to and from the arena. That's the best time to catch a picture with them. I am always surprised how humble the wrestlers are. Some wrestlers will smile and even joke with you!if you're new to Sumo, a tour with a guide is easily the best way to experience it. But. You can do it on your own!One last thing: it's a long day, so you may want to bring snacks with you. The concession stands can completely sell out of bento lunch boxes, so You can get pretty hungry by the end of the day. I bring in snacks in my small backpack without a problem. Oh yeah flying your pillow and the end of a match that was really good or, the last match of the day you will see pillows flying, officially this is a no no. But when Rome!! Also when the last match ends don't be in a rush to leave. There is actually a closing ceremony that is performed. It is worth watching.Have fun! Interact with the he locals next to you this is a fun sport and you will enjoy being among the locals and watching their national sport.

Terrific experience . This is a great experience and not just for the Sumo aficionado.It is theatre not just a contest (albeit serious).Best advice is to make sure you get some background for what you are watching because even though we had watched Sumo before (on television) understanding the back story is important in appreciating what you are watching.First we went for Three days but the first day was with a tour company (Viator) and the guide supplied a cheat sheet on each contestant which we were able to use at each of the other two days.Second I recommend you do get the little wireless to get the English translation for the main matches from 4pm. Again to help with context.Third if possible you go for tickets in the first three rows on level2 (level 1 is the ground floor) if not at least in the lower section of level 2. There are no bad seats but it gets a little remote up the back.All in all not to be missed uniquely Japanese.

Flying pillows. You will be in for the long haul if you decide to go early. The big names are several hours later in the final bouts. Worth it if you are mildly in to Sumo. Otherwise go later in the day and watch the action and the crowds go crazy... Japan-style.

A must-see if you're in Japan whilst a tournament is on. We saw one of the first couple of days of the tournament in May 2016 and it was one of the highlights of our entire trip.As I'd seen others recommend, we arrived a little after lunch when the higher ranked matches start and despite my partner saying "I don't think we'll stay to the end" (it was about 4 hours away) we actually did stay until the last match because it was that good.I'm not much of a sports person, but I think because the matches are so quick and you can never tell who will win just based on their size, it definitely held our attention the whole time. I also like the idea that while it is a contact sport, it's not anywhere near as violent as many other sports.The arena itself has very good seating all over, so you can always see what's going on, however I would recommend getting seating in the lowest portion of the second level - we had tickets a little up from that section, and while we could still see everything, we definitely will pay a little more to get a little closer next time.Highly recommend this as it's an experience unique to Japan and very entertaining.

Summer Basho such an experience. Attending the Summer Basho tournament was a fabulous experience. Fortunately we booked on a guided tour and our guide was amazing. She explained everything about the history, tradition and rules of sumo without which we may have struggled a bit to understand. Absolutely worth going to a tournament when you visit Tokyo to be totally immersed in their culture.

Tuornament very interesting. I was there just to see the building, after the visit to the close Edo' - Tokyo Museum. So was very nice to discover that, during the tournament I can easily buy the ticket and go inside.I saw an interesting part of it.

What an experience. If your in Tokyo and the Sumo is on, definitely a must do on the list. Try and get tickets for the days the finals are on. The crowd really get into it. But saying that we enjoyed day one just as much. The experience was amazing, we didnt have the radio for English and still thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Get assistance to locate your seats and enjoy. The stadium is very close to the train line so finding it is easy. We purchased tickets through buysumotickets and the service was amazing cannot fault them. Arranged delivery of the tickets to our hotel and upon check in they were there

Sumo May Tournament Tokyo. One of the highlights of our trip. Sumo starts at 8am and finishes at 6pm, we arrived around midday and left around 5.15pm to beat the huge crowds. It doesn't get busy until after three when the better sumo's fight. The sport dates back approx 2 thousand years and there is a lot of tradition to this sport. Whilst the wrestle usually lasts no longer than fifteen seconds it's very exciting to watch and the lead up to the fight is where you will see a lot of the tradition and rituals. I think I'll start watching sumo on tv/internet when I return home from my trip, I looked up the full history of sumo because I had such a great day. If you can time a trip to Japan when the tournaments are on it is Definately worth it. There are six each year due to the popularity of sumo, do your research in advance because this is a must !!

Great stadium to watch sumo!. I loved this experience. We bought our tickets a month in advance for 3,800 yen per person, and we got seats all the way at the high back, but it was fine so long as you remember two things: (1) binoculars and (2) you can just sit in the seats that are "reserved" on the second floor but closest to the ring until the people fill in at about 3:40 PM, or when the best wrestlers start to go to the ring. People are usually pretty nice about it.The stadium itself is also a museum, and has lots of souvenirs on sale, though they're at pretty high prices. Lots of foreigners came, which was cool to see - they wanted the sumo experience, too! I actually got pretty into the experience, especially when Ishiura won: he was a small guy but managed to shove the big guy out of the ring! Watching the last three matches (the ones with the yokozuna, the best fighters [all three are from Mongolia]) was incredibly interesting, and the audience went wild.The sumo wrestlers spend a lot of time trying to intimidate each other and getting as ready as can be, making eye contact and taunting, but once they go at each other, it's so much fun to watch. Good fighters go on from about 2:15 PM, and the best ones start around 3:40 PM. It lasted until 6 PM for us, and four hours was just enough time, methinks; not too much and not too little!

Sumo Tournament a must when in Tokyo!. We were fortunate enough to buy tickets to the second day of the Sumo tournament at the Ryogoku Kokugikan. Easy train access to the venue from central Tokyo, only costs around 300yen each way. The venue is huge and entry starts from 8am, it doesn't start to get busy until after the tea ceremony at 2.20pm. If you get in early you can sneak down to the private boxes on level one and watch some matches up close. By 3.30pm the venue was really starting to fill up, seats on the second level are much more comfortable and offer a bird's eye view. The venue states that you cannot bring outside food or drinks, however this rule did not appear to be enforced. We had no trouble bringing in lunch and bottles of water/soft drink from the local supermarket. Food and Beverages offered at reasonable prices at the venue. Would highly recommend going.

Sumo Hall. It is not only a stadium but also a museum. Murals are colorful at the entrance of the building and when walking in, it is interesting to see some history about the Sumo players themselves. We did not attend any match but I guess I should make a point to do so on my next trip. Japanese just love Sumo wrestling.

Lucky to see the competition. We were lucky to get tickets to the exhibition show of the season. This was one of my bucket list and I was able to see the sumo wrestling matches live. I had a memorable time and it definitely was a lot more fun than watching it on the tv. Double thumbs up!

Sumo. Always visit Asakusa in May for sanja matsuri and sumo basho. The arena is amazing if you stand outside before the main sumo bouts you can watch the higher ranked wrestlers entering the building, great atmosphere especially hearing the ladies shouting the name of their favourite

A Day at the SUMO. I was in Tokyo in September 2015 when the SUMO Championships were on and was very keen to see a match and try to understand what it is all about. Tried to get tickets but too hard. Heard from other travellers that if you go to the Stadium very early in the morning (ie 7am) and line up you can get a ticket. So I did, stood in the line and an attendant comes and gives you a token for the general seats which you hand in and get a ticket for that day.Note you have to stand in line which fills up quick, you only get 1 token per person so you can get more for others, tickets are only for that day and once in you cannot go out and re-entre..We spent most of the day there which was ok because it was raining and companions tiered from long plane trip so suited us.Very enjoyable saw 8 hours of SUMO wrestling so got my fill.Worth going if the SUMO are on but best fighters on between 1pm and close at 5pm.

Truly interesting place to visit ... we could not get tickets for the Super January tourney though :(. Truly interesting place to visit ... we could not get tickets for the Super January tourney though :(It was cool to see all of the cool banners and murals outside and all of the sumos going in and out ... plus the structure itself is nice to admire.

Nothing much to do there. We arrived hoping to be able to see inside the arena but it wasn't open to the publicWent in the museum but wasn't much there I bet it would be great when it is all open but unfortunately nothing much to do otherwise

Must go!!. You will have a great time with your family. One big warning, DO NOT BUY TICKETS FROM: BUYSUMOTICKETS.COM!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!They bait and switch their tickets. Beware, they will promise you something and give you something else in return.

2016-0207 Chinese New Year's Eve with Sumo wrestling in Japan. Before I came to Japan, I am the one of all watch the sumo wrestling on TV. I came to Japan several times, but this time is my first time watch live sumo wrestling show. The wrestlers seem to be very fat, but their body is flexible and strong. Just like to listening the musical drama or concert, it is not so easy to express the real feeling to the others without this experience.Seeing is believing. Just watch a sumo match and you’ll see!

Awesome insight into local culture. We visited during the Grand Sumo tournament.We booked through buysumotickets.com - Jeff was extremely helpful answering my questions.The experience itself was phenomenal and offered a terrific insight into Japanese legend and culture. The atmosphere increases throughout the day until the Yokozunas enter the ring which is a sight to behold. The bouts are quite short (a few seconds) but there are many of them to keep you entertained.Can't recommend enough if you're in town at the right time.

Great day at the Sumo Tournament. We booked this thru Viator - JTB Sunrise Tours. Great day. Our tour guide spoke reasonably good English and she prepared us on what to expect handing out copies of who was wrestling in each match along with their stats. This really made the whole day come together. Although our seats were rather high up we did have a very clear view of each match. We were so fortunate to be in Tokyo when the tournament was going on. I would highly recommend spending a day and using JTB to help you get acclimated to what to expect. One of those unexpectedly great day tours.
Should visit once. This is the place where sumo takes place. Suma is a minute or less play. So for many people it may be boring.

A must see if in Tokyo at the right time. We attended day 6 of the most recent tournament and enjoyed it a lot. We bought our tickets well in advance through BuySumoTickets - this was well worth the effort and cost as we could plan our trip around the date we had. We chose A grade seats and had an excellent view of the ring. Spending the 300JPY on the radio to hear the live commentary was money well spent. For a great afternoon of entertainment in a uniquely Japanese way you must go to the sumo. It is good for people watching as well as the actual sumo

So much fun. If you are in Tokyo when the Sumo Tournament is on it should be at the top of your to do list. Its quite hard to get tickets so book early, they were sold out when we booked but we got them through a tour company, which I highly recommend, our tour guide was amazing, she gave us so much information on the tournament, sumo in general and each of the competitors. The atmosphere was amazing at the tournament, it was a great experience.

Interesting experience and the pre fight ceremony also worth experiencing. The tickets we got are valid for the whole day however we only view for an hour before we got bored. It is overall still a great experience to bring back home and to tick off the bucket list.

Sumo tournament final!. Went to the sumo tournament final today (24 January 2016) and the atmosphere was incredible. We had a 4 person box on the 1st (ground) floor and we had a great view of the ring. Kotoshogiku beat Goeido to become champhion (yokozuna) - the first Japanese sumo to become champion in more than a decade. Great atmosphere, great cultural experience - would really recommend. Tickets can be hard to get so book in advance - box tickets were about 9,500 yen each.

Such a great experience!. Booked a sumo tour on viator.com and chose the Keio Plaza Hotel as the pick up place. Tour guide was great. Michiko is an avid sumo fan and she explained all the sumo rules for us. The atmosphere at the arena was great! There are a lot of food stands so you won't get hungry. So glad we chose to catch the Sumo Grand Tournament!

Must do if you are there when on. What a great way to spend the day. We got a 4 person box which fitted 2 adults and a child. There are English guide books available to help you understand what's going on. Grab some beers and a bento box, and enjoy the spectacle.Beware it sells out well in advance so get in early for tickets.

Sumo is good fun. In Tokyo, Sumo tournaments are held in January, May and September. If you get the chance, they are well worth the cost of admission. Although the lower ranks start around 2pm, I recommend getting to the kokugikan around 3:15-3:30z. This will give you time to look around, but some beer and snacks and find your seat before the upper level begins. I highly recommend renting a radio for play by play. There is an English NHK commentary available that makes the experience a lot more enjoyable. The rental cost is 200 yen, but bring cash because they require an additional 3000 yen deposit which you get back upon return. We also sit up high in stadium seating. The first level seating is considered better but you sit in 4 person boxes with cushions instead of seats- better view but murder on the knees. There really aren't any bad views in the stadium.
Grand Sumo Tournament. Attended the Grand Sumo Tournament, really nice and funny to see, great ambience. Good view from Main side, B-chairs (boxes would've been nice but for four persons).
Must do. Our second time at the sumo in Tokyo. We had a box seat for four. Very cosy especially for anyone with long legs. Book your tickets online way ahead of time or you will miss out.

Sumo Spectacular. Big Blokes, Beer and Bento. It really doesn't get any better than this! This is a fantastic way to spend a cold afternoon.Our family of 4 took a box at the Sumo thinking it would be worth popping in fair an hour or so. Four hours later, we left thoroughly entertained. The box was just big enough for a family of 4, as long as the kids aren't too big. Very comfy for 2 people, but possibly a bit tight for 4 larger adults.It is a relaxed atmosphere, and you can come and go as you please. The food is great and you can eat & drink in your box. You can see all of the action from the c class box, which is a little cheaper.The sumo itself was fantastic. I am not really all that into sport, but the whole psychology, ceremony and physicality of the event was incredible. Make sure you duck out the back of the souvenir stands to see the big blokes walking in to the stadium. They are awesome!

What a hoot!. Despite no interest or experience with sumo, this was a great opportunity to see Japan for real. The helpful map and radio translation made it interesting and as the crowd built and the master sumo began, it was a thrill to be involved and witness this unique Japanese sport.

Huge is the only way to describe this place!. The world famous Ryogoku Sumo Museum & Arena is situated next to a train station & also adjacent to the Edo Tokyo Museum making for a very handy place to visit to get a taste of Japanese culture. When I visited it was closed to the public due to an annual Sumo function but it was still worth hanging around outside to catch a glimpse of the sumo - probably better due to the fact they were all assembled in one place at the same time - made for a very impressive spectacle.

What an experience!. If you are looking for an authentic Japanese sports experience go for a day of Sumo wrestling! If you come here early in the morning you can walk up all to way to the 'arena' to watch the action up close. In the afternoon (ask what time at the stadium) the good (and big) wrestlers come walking to the stadium so you can watch them close by.

The Real Japan. This was such a unique experience as an American onlooker. The event was well organized, ran on time, and was super fun to watch and easy to get into! Great entertainment! I probably won't need to return as the originally novelty is worn off but I do think a one time visit is a must do for visitors to Japan! What a wonderful window into a fascinating part of the Japanese culture! As with most sports the closer you can get to the action the better. So pick seats as close to the ring as possible!

Ryogoku Kokugikan. we went to see the grand sumo tournament at November, the tournaments runs for couple of days, its start from the morning and run until the evening, so to see the best rank fighters come at 15:00 and stay till 19:00.its amazing to see al the fights and the traditional rituals of the Tournament.The crowd is very involved and cheers the fighters from all over the world.Well-built stadium, and while we were sitting in higher stands we had a good view of the arena.An experience not to be missed!

Worth a visit. We were fortunate to be visiting Tokyo during one of their tournaments and bought the tickets online in advance which was slightly confusing but we got there in the end. The sumo itself was awe inspiring. We got tickets in the higher stands but could see the fights quite clearly and even though we didn't understand it all, we would recommend it for the history of the place and the culture of the sport. There were legions of fans awaiting to greet sumo rockstars as they got out of their limos. Was a great sight to behold the reverence the Japanese have. We also got some really nice sumo banners from the stalls in the foyer.

Amazing!. We had good seats - though the sightlines are good from anywhere. The hall got fuller as the highlight bouts got nearer - 3.30 onwards. You can eat and drink in your seats if you wish, but the action (though we didn't really understand it!) was gripping, even if the actual "close encounters" were very brief ... the pageantry, the colour, the costumes, the NOISE were really amazing. Probably worth not rushing for the station at the end, as 3 million people were doing the same thing!

Major home of Sumo. After attending sumo at Nagoya and Fukuoka, September was my first visit to Ryogoku Kokugikan (actually twice in the same week). Personally, as I like and actively follow the sumo, I was more interested in the action on the inside, but as an attraction, there is a small museum with some interesting displays which would occupy a fan for 1/2 hour or so.The stadium itself has two floors. Even from the cheap seats up the back, the view is good and you can see all of the action on and around the ring. For the box seats, fitting four adults in is a bit of a squeeze, especially if tall like myself) and it can get uncomfortable after a while, but there is enough around the concourse to look at (souvenirs, food), that a day passes pretty quickly.
Sumo Tournament . The tickets were sold out however we did manage to buy the open tickets. We had to queue for ticket since 5am. Anyway it's worth watching the Sumo fight. Great experience.

Interesting venue. I visited Ryogoku Kokugikan for the New Japan Pro Wrestling "King of Pro Wrestling" event.An interesting arena designed for sumo. Great views of the action even from the back of the hall. Easy to reach on foot from Akihabara or central Tokyo if you don't mind walking, also a train station and metro adjacent to the venue.

Everyone will enjoy a day of watching sumo wrestling. This arena hosts sumo wrestling competitions 3 times a year, lasting 14 days each time, so check the calendar if you are going to Japan on a leisure trip. The matches start at 8 am and keep on until 6 pm at a relentless pace with next two bouting pairs lined up at all times. This is something all ages and men and women can enjoy together. It is very interesting to watch the bouts and the rituals around it. Make a bet to enjoy it more. I would recommend to splash out on a box seat on ground level which is dimensioned for 4 people, but realistically only fits 2 Westerners.Then for lunch, go to top floor and have Japanese food. There was a bit of a queue when we arrived at 1130, but cleared fairly quickly. It was probably the best Japanese food we had during our 2 week trip.Then at the end, you can watch the sumo wrestlers come and go from the arena. There was quite a big crowd when we were there and you can do that even if you dont have any tickets to the arena also. To see the wrestlers up close gives you an idea of how massive (and tall) some of them are. And many are not Japanese either.We went on a weekday 2/3 into the competition and it was not so many people there in the morning, but then when the higher divisions start in the afternoon there were more people arriving.

Unique Experience. During May of this past year I watched one a series of Sumo Wrestling bouts at the Ryogoku Kokugikan. I honestly do not think there is a bad place to sit in this venue. Great view from where we were sitting, and other parts of the venue were awesome as well. The bouts were exciting to watch as well. The washrooms were easy to find, and it was just as easy to navigate throughout the arena. I would recommend coming here for events.

Surprisingly very enjoyable!. We booked this through Viator before arriving in Japan. Thought it would be fun for hubby and FIL. We ALL really enjoyed it. Our tour guide (english speaking) was fabulous and really gave us good background information to help us understand. We when arrived at Tournament, we were given portable radios with earbuds to listen to the English speaking commentators. We had a great time!

Highlight of our trip. For me, this is the highlight of our trip. We were able to watch Sumo Wrestling live! We had to queue from 6am to get the tickets but it was all worth it. There is a museum inside and lots of kiosks to buy snacks. Saw some famous wrestlers pass by and the fans just went crazy. If you have the chance to watch, you can rent a radio so you can actually hear the commentators in English. It was a very interesting experience. They sell beer inside the stadium too!

Had a blast. We booked tickets to see a grand sumo tournament. We got there about 3pm and stayed until the end at around 6pm.It was one of the highlights of our trip and a must do if a tournament is on. Our 9 year old was glued to the matches the whole time.We booked our tickets from Australia through buysumotickets.com. They were most helpful and also arranged tickets to the Ghibli museum for us too. The tickets were couriered to us.

Fun day at Sumo tournament . Going to Ryogoku Kokugikan was a really interesting and fun experience. The stadium has two levels of seating. The bottom half of the audience sits on the floor on thin cushions which got uncomfortable for me in about 20 minutes since I'm not used to it. We spent time on the second level where my assigned seats were which I actually preferred not just for having a regular chair with food tray attached but the angle made the sumo matches easy to watch.During the sumo tournament there are vendors selling souvenirs and food. The nice thing about the shirts is that sizes go all the way to XXXL, which makes sense since I bet majority of sumo wear Rick Ross sizes themselves. The food is real basic snacks, the prices are reasonable, but bringing your own snacks and food into the stadium (which is allowed) is a much better option. They do however have a restaurant on the second floor that serves Japanese Food including the Sumo Stable Food called Chanko Nabe. The sumo tournament itself is fun to watch, all the matches from about 3pm to 6pm the crowd really gets into. In between matches however be prepared for monotonous/redundant chanting along with ritualistic stuff. The Japanese are an ancient society, despite being modern they feel strongly about tradition and you really see that in the tournament. Important Tip: the men's bathroom on the second floor have toilets. First floor requires squatting.

The modern and the traditional meet in a collision of sumo. Fantastic experience if you can go when there is a tournament on. There are three annually at the Tōkyō stadium which seats 13,000 people. there are plenty of food stalls and souvenirs are available. The museum which is normally open to the public is only open to paying spectators during tournaments. Tickets really should be bought in advance via the Sumo Association's website as they are usually sold out. There are english speaking volunteers at the gates to guide you through how to get your pre purchased tickets from the ticket dispensing machines. The top ranking riskishi (wrestlers) start arriving at the South gate at 2pm and this is a good photo opportunity. From 2pm onward the stadium starts to fill up as the top ranking wrestlers take to the dohyo (ring) and take part in ceremonials before they start to wrestle. This continues till around 6pm. There are people who carry pressurized beer containers around the stadium seating so you can purchase a beer at your seat. English language guides are available to make the experience more enjoyable and English language radio commentary from 4pm onwards.

2Fの椅子席3列目. 毎回、千秋楽には相撲観戦に行きます。１Fの升席よりも、案外、２Fの椅子席3列目くらいのほうがよく見えるし、足も楽だと思います。ラジオを持っていったほうがいいかなー、レンタルできるけど。毎回味が変わるちゃんこは並んで食べたほうがいいです。あと、ひよの山最中アイスが結構おいしいです。I come here each final day of the tournament. I recommend taking the ticket for the 3rd stage sheet at the Second floor because better view than the tail end of first floor. Especially you can take a comfortable own sheet more than the first floor. The First floor sheets are narrow space and high cost. Sumo has a lot of fine rules and nice cultures more than you see, I recommend taking a guide with you. The Chanko is daily changed, it will be popular and long line but you should be in the line and eat it, very good. Probably 200 yen about.I liked an ice cream of Hiyonoyama, it is good. Hiyonoyama is a mascot character of Sumo, it's cute!

Don't understand it but loved it!. We popped in with our children (boys ages 3 and 5) for a quick look at the museum and were lucky enough there was a charity tournament on. For a small donation we could enter and sit wherever we liked, started up the back on western style seats then moved down to the floor seating a bit later. We didn't plan to stay long but it was quite addictive and the boys didn't want to leave. We were probably there for about 2 hours, did not understand it, but it was such a spectacle that we were all mesmerised, I would highly recommend getting tickets if I had realised how entertaining it was!

Sumo with a 5 year old. It’s absolutely fine to take children to the sumo. Our five-year old son was quite interested in what was going on and we managed to stay for around 3 hours, with a short break and walk up the street about halfway through.The day we went was sold-out. The arena opens at 8am but we arrived at around 1:30pm. Go to Ryogoku (E12) metro station and take exit 3. Follow the signs for the Edo Tokyo museum (the big ship like building) and walk down the side of it. You will see the traditional green stadium roof behind. It’s fairly easy to find.We booked our tickets online on the day they went on sale through the official website which linked to Oosumo tickets. It was all in English although we weren’t quite sure which row our seats were in until we got there. We chose the seated section (Arena) section A. It cost 25500 yen for 3 tickets. We were in the 3rd row and had excellent views. The mats on the floor below looked cool, but I don’t think you’d be comfortable for very long.You must take the credit card that you paid for your tickets with, as well as the ticket number, to get your actual tickets from a machine. There were no queues to collect tickets when we arrived, despite it being sold-out. We did have a bit of difficulty finding our seats because the tickets are mostly written in Japanese – so it was a case of ‘match the symbol to the one on the door’. The seat numbers are written in Western numbers though and were easy to find once we found the correct door. Our son had a notebook and some pens as well as a bag of snacks to keep him occupied when his attention to the sumo did wane. The people around us were very tolerant. It’s a happy atmosphere and my son seemed to be most welcome, although we didn’t see any other children there.Sumo is quite a spectacle. The banner displays, and the pre-bout manoeuvring and salt throwing between the two wrestlers takes far longer than the actual wrestle – with some bouts over in about 5 seconds once they started. I don’t think we saw any that lasted more than 30 seconds. We saw a few sumos land on top of the judges in the front row. It’s quite colourful and the crowd really gets into it, cheering on their favourites.There are souvenir stalls and food outlets around the venue. We bought popcorn and drinks but you can get hot Japanese meals as well. We walked up the street to the Seven Eleven to stock up on snacks half-way through. You are allowed one pass-out. You can eat inside the stadium while watching the wrestlers.Check out the ‘toilet flushing noise’ button in the toilets – it does nothing except make a toilet flushing noise. (One of those ‘only in Japan’ moments.)Sumos are generally happy to pose for photos in and around the stadium although I wouldn’t interrupt them on their way in to wrestle. You can watch them arrive if you go outside on the ground floor, and take photos of them in their Yukutas.You can also take photos (no flash) inside the stadium.We didn’t stay until the very end because I was dreading how crowded the metro platform would be once the sumo had finished. But we saw enough to make it worthwhile. We saw the entrance ceremonies for the grandmasters and the next level down. You will be given a leaflet in English which shows who is wrestling and the approximate times for them making their entry (when all the sumos get up on the ring and raise their hands). Worth seeing and hearing the crowd cheer.Sumo is only on at certain times of the year – so check out in advance if it’s on when you are in Japan, and when the tickets go on sale.We don’t usually watch any sport, but this was one of the highlights of our holiday!

Sumo-tastic. Went here to watch the sumo and it was an amazing experience. Loved how different is was to sports you normally see. The building itself was nice and traditional looking. Lots food and drink stalls inside. We booked online from UK and on the day there were signs saying it was sold out so probably something you need to plan in advance. If there is a tournament on while you are in Tokyo we would definately recommend going.

If you can get tickets, highly recommended. Tickets are hard to get but if you can get it, it will be once in a life time experience. The bout begins from early morning but go around 2 pm for couple of hours leading to the grand champion bouts. If you can get masu or box, go for it. They say 4 person but would say 3 to sit comfortably. Bring butt protector as sitting is on hard floor. Can eat and drink while bout is going on. Ask travel agent to see if they can get tickets and also ask about rituals about buying food and drinks. Here, tips are recommended for server.

Fantastic event. I was eagerly looking forward to seeing a sumo tournament and was not disappointed. It was a fantastic spectacle and very interesting experience. Went with Sunrise tours - well organised using trains, english speaking guide, good seats with a good view on an upper tier (compared to sitting on mats on the floor at the lower level). Guide gave good information before arriving at the venue and provided radios with english commentary. Arrived at the venue just as the higher ranked wrestlers were starting (about 3PM) and went through to 6PM when the tournament finished. I would recommend this to anyone who is in Tokyo when the tournaments are on (about three times a year in Tokyo).

Great event. We had a great time at Sumo Tournament. Seating is mats on a floor in a box, which did become uncomfortable, but people walking around serving ice cold beer made it bearable.Their is much ceremony and fanfare but the whole theatre of it was excellent and the excitement to each match is great fun.Highly recommend it as an afternoon out

Top thing to do in Tokyo . I can't rate the sumo enough, it's amazing not just the sumo but the whole event. Even though I couldn't understand the commentary it was amazing. Our tickets allowed us to enter early in the morning but the auditorium didn't fill up until nearer 3 o clock. Unless you like sitting cross legged I'd suggest getting the western seating which is higher up but you can still view everything clearly. One tip you can only exit the auditoroum and Reiner once so if

SUMO ROCKS!. Had a great time, buy the normal seats unless your a superficial floor sitter. Facility is very nice, bathroom stop notch, cool, comfortable, restaurants good, next to station.What a spectacle! Loved all the matches, we stayed all day!

Amazing sumo experience!. We were here during the Autumn tournament so got tickets early on the day (2200YEN) around 8.30am, then came back in the afternoon. The stadium gradually filled up. Hard to get to grips with a foreign sport like this but was definitely an eye-opener!

Once in a lifetime experience! . Wow! Not really into sumo but figured "when in Tokyo" and we did not regret. Weren't organised enough to book ahead of time so had to rely on on the day tickets. Got to the stadium about 7:45 am and were given a ticket to hold whilst we waited in line for the real ticket. This was to reserve our place- they only sell 350 extra tickets each day and we got tickets 347 and 348 so if you wanted to guarantee ur tickets, I'd get there earlier. You're allowed one re entry each day. We went in around 1pm and the lower level guys are on but ended up staying right though until 6pm as the atmosphere was infective! We hired a radio for 200yen (+3000 yen deposit that is returned after). Comes with head phones for one ear so if you wanted to share between two - bring your own head phones. This had English commentary from 4:30pm onwards and this was invaluable for us as it really allowed us to get into the spirit and understand what is going on. Would definitely go again!

A very long day but worth it. Having been disappointed the day before, I queued up at 6am to get tickets. General admission seats are in the top row but it's still easy enough to see the action. There are matches non stop until 5.30/6ish so my advice would be to go in and reserve a decent seat (everybody appears to just put a programme down), watch a few of the games and then leave the grounds (make sure to get stamped) before returning around 2.45 for the big boys. I stayed all day and was very drained by the end of it so its best to go elsewhere. As a sumo first timer I did find it a little difficult to understand what was going on but it was thoroughly enjoyable!!

Sumo tournament-one of the most amazing things I've ever seen. If you can you really must try to go to Tokyo in sumo tournament season. You can find the dates in the website. This was definitely one of the highlights of our trip to Japan. So interesting and thrilling to see these big fighters practicing a sport that has remained largely unchanged for so many years. I recommend reading about the meaning of the rituals, the history of the sport, and how the rankings work while you're there. I also found that info in the website. Purchase your tickets online cause they go fast and it's always sold out.

Not missing out on tickets 101. Absolutely shattered I couldn't get to see this! Pre-plan to buy the limited tickets for the tournament so you don't miss out if you know you'll be around when a tournament is on. The dates and ticket information can all be found online. If you didn't score a ticket tickets can be purchased on the day. There is a limit of 350 tickets sold at 8am and unfortunately for us it was a public holiday on the day we attempted to purchase tickets. Arriving at 7am we missed out on tickets by 6 people in the line! Some days you can still purchase tickets after 9 but every day would be different so I recommend going early. You are allowed one re-entry so purchase them, go about your day and come back around 3 when the better matches begin.

September Grand Tournament. This was one of those things that if we had the chance we were going to do during our trip to Japan. Having looked at the website when we first planned this trip, we came prepared, having pre-booked our tickets within hours of the tickets becoming available. Even so we got some of the last, so make sure you book as early as possible!! We got the cheapest available seats as we weren't sure whether we would enjoy the sumo or not. As it turns out it was fascinating to watch and follow, even though we didn't get the English commentary. Most things were either fairly self explanatory, or easily explained with a little pre=visit research. The cheap seats are incredibly high up so if you don't like heights they're probably not a good choice, but they do still give you a good view of everything that is going on, and you feel very much a part of events. Both my husband and I really enjoyed our afternoon at the sumo and would thoroughly recommend that if you can, you should try to go! Having said that, the group behind us got quite bored, getting irritated with the rituals and ceremonies that accompanied each bout. Personally I loved it, for an afternoon.The two best groups of sumo wrestlers don't arrive or start their bouts until about 2pm so there is plenty of time to use your ticket that also gives you entry to the museum next door (this is free outside of tournament times but only ticket holders can get in when the tournaments are being held).We weren't sure whether there would be food available at the arena and if there was, how expensive it would be. It was a nice surprise that there was a wide range with bento boxes from around 1400 yen and snacks from about 300 yen. I had the fried noodles for 400 yen and they were lovely!Quick Tip: Arrive and depart using the Toei Oedo Line rather than the JR Line. It may be 10 minutes closer on foot but you will be fighting for space, especially on the return journey!

Sumo and Edo museum in one day. We were able to buy day-of tickets for the tournament. A had time to kill before the real activities started so went next door to the Edo museum. You are allowed one re-admittance. Came back around 2:30. We also rented the radio for the English commentary, which was helpful. We sat in the last row but that was ok as any other tickets would have been more expensive. Sumo was surprisingly interesting. This is probably going to be one of those things I just do once.

Book,plan ahead to avoid disappointment. We went to stadium and it was closed as it was a Japanese holiday period which wasnt mentioned on the website. And then further research revealed that we can only watch sumo wrestling if booked in advanced at certain times and dates.

Gave it a 3 just because the tickets were sold out lol. Always enjoyed seeing sumo on tv. I was hoping to catch a show but it was sold out. That being said- the area is very neat and the arena is huge

Make sure the tournament is on!. A great building and it is really cool seeing the sumos wandering around. Far less to do when there is not a tournament on but at the same time there are quite a few sites in the general area which make it worth your time.

host sumo wrestling. if you are in Tokyo during the sumo tournament make sure to get some tickets. Be there from 3 pm and you will get to see the biggest sumo stars. Well worth the money and a good way to experience true Japanese culture.

Culturally, a good experience. You can go in May before the season starts and watch a training session for free. Best to get in early, we arrived at 9am and 3/4 full. Japanese very passionate about their sumo wrestlers, waiting out the front to get autographs and just to pat their favorites on the back.

Unique experience. We were lucky enough to be visiting Tokyo at the same time as the Sumo tournament was being held and so decided to book tickets, as we figured this was a unique opportunity and we would not be able to see this elsewhere. I had never seen (or was not very knowledgeable about) Sumo before and neither had my boyfriend, but we were blown away! We got there around 2pm and stayed for the full four hours until close, it was just incredible. Didn't see the time go by - it's surprisingly intense to watch. We were sat in the B section in regular seats, which were comfortable and good value, we had no problems with the view.

Diapers on grown men never looked so cool!. I'm a little biased since I dreamed of seeing sumo first hand ever since high school, but if you are even thinking about seeing sumo even a minuscule amount then think no further and do it! There is so much rich history about Japan within the sport itself. Read the book "The Big Book of Sumo" by Mina Hallhttp://www.amazon.com/Big-Book-Sumo-History-Practice/dp/1880656280/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1437943286&sr=8-1&keywords=the+big+book+of+sumoGives a lot of information about the sport from the history to the rules.While walking around the district you may be lucky enough to run into some of the sumo wrestlers. The energy in the arena was more than I accepted and made the matches that much more enjoyable.If you want a more visual look check out this episode of Japan VS where an overview of the arena and matches are gone over:https://youtu.be/tZJvzp8N4ks?t=3m6s

Transcendental. A fabulous, unforgettable experience. It is truly inspiring to see dignity and the humble respect for tradition at work. The wrestlers are friendly and happy to pose for pictures. Lifelong memories await all who enter this magical place.

Sumo Stadium. As we all know, Japan has one of the unique attractions of by his body, which is Sumo. Well this is where you can see various performances sumo in Japan. Please see the schedule on the internet, and you should not miss!

Sumo wrestling. Wonderful spectacle - even my wife enjoyed it!. This is a spectacle which should not be missed. It only occurs in the Sumo season so you need to be aware of that.My wife went with me, grudgingly, as it was something I really wanted to see. However, she really enjoyed the event, much to her surprise.You need to get there around 3pm (which is when the best matches start) or earlier and it is over around 6pm.If you want to eat in the vicinity, it is best to book as thousands spill out after the event.
Sumo. June 2015, very easy to find. Any problems ask a local, the museum contains some very interesting facts about Sumo and their history, with photos and garments worn for tournaments.

Sumo tournament was special. We were lucky enough to be in Tokyo during one of their tournaments and took the advice to get their early 9.30am and gained entry. Weren't many tickets left at this time. Despite being allocated seats up high the locals don't tend to come until later in the day or evening so we quietly sat on one of the lower levels, they didn't check tickets so this was no problem. Although we saw the lower divisions wrestle it was fascinating and I have a greater appreciation of the techniques required to compete. We even got to meet and chat to a Canadian Sumo who was competing

Fantastic afternoon and evening at the Ryogoku sumo wrestlers venue. I went to see sumo wrestling with an arranged tour by japanican.com/Sunrise Tours. After the meetup at Hamamatsucho st. I went by train to Ryogoku along with the group and friendly guide, Ms. Ohno, to see wrestling and after that chanko dinner at a nearby restaurant.It was an interisting insight to the traditional sport of Japan.
The finest sumo arena. The sumo arena is beautiful, in my opinion. Since I love sumo, I am truly happy whenever I go to Ryogoku Kokugikan.

Buy a chair seat. As a person who watches no sport on TV or goes to stadiums, I wasn't expecting the sumo to be so captivating. We were in Tokyo on Day 8 of the May competition, and watched it for 5 hours without losing interest. I was hesitant to go earlier in the day because I had heard the more professional levels don't appear until 3:30pm but the lower-level bouts were still very interesting. In fact, possibly more interesting since you could get wild mis-matches in size between wrestlers, and it's always good value to watch a man the size of two fridges square off against a man the size of a small truck. :-)Food didn't seem cheap in there - we bought snacks at Family Mart before entry. You can hire English radio translations in there if they're available, for a refundable deposit of 2000 yen and a total fee of only 100 yen. When we arrived, we were told they were all in use and to return at 2:30pm. I went back at 2:40pm and they were all gone again, so I never found out what was available - no matter, you can easily work it out without assistance.I recommend a chair seat not only for the comfort but also because the people in the floor seats are only located about 6-8 inches higher than the people in front of them (which could give you a bad view). Also, the complexity of getting cross-legged into a small space meant many people took a long time to sit down, blocking the view of those behind them.

A great spectacle. We had tickets for the Tokyo May 2015 tournament and spent 5 hours watching Sumo and eating sushi, snacks and drinking Japanese beer! A great afternoon. Despite understanding only part of what was going on, it was good fun. The facilities at the arena were excellent. If you are in Japan when the tournament is in Tokyo I would say go and watch!

One of THE highlights of my visits to Japan. We had a great four hours there for one of the tournaments, and was lucky to sit next to two Japanese ladies who explained a bit in broken Japanese/English and sign language and we soon joined them in loud support of various wrestlers.It's dead easy to book tickets at any 7/11 store and our seats cost just 5,100 yen which gave us excellent views of the bouts and stadium. I walked all around the arean and views from anywhere were fine.Snacks and drinks readily available
