Sumo wrestling was the HIGHLIGHT of Japan!. I am not a sports person, I am not one to watch basketball, soccer or cricket on televison however I fell in love with Sumo Wrestling after being in Ryogoku Kokugikan! This was really the highlight of the trip, everyone n the stadium gets really into the game! There was a nice old man who sat next to me and did not speak English but still kept trying to talk to me about the match - his enthusiasm was infectious! Highly recommend watching a sumo match if you're in Japan during sumo season - you will not regret it

A must see, when its on. These a two week events, that happen every other months (1,3,5,..). We were lucky to be in town. Had seen this many times in TV but live its so much better. Simply enjoy the atmosphere, the rituals, but also the japanese audience, enjoying a truely japanese sport.

I enjoyed the tournament. I had fun watching the tournament and drinking beer. This is a good way to learn a little about Japanese culture. Purchase tickets in advance! The seats you want might sell out in minutes! And make sure your credit card company knows you intend on using the card for an international transaction. My card was blocked and my credit card company contacted me regarding possible fraud.

Possibly the best thing you can do in Tokyo. Find someone to buy you tickets and splurge for the good seats. Watching sumo live is a once-in-a-lifetime experience, well worth the cost. Pay for the English coverage is worth it (100 yen) and it gives you live, play-by-play analysis. Go outside from the first floor towards the food vendors and you can see the wrestlers as they leave after their bouts. Most are very happy to pose for photos and sign autographs. Definitely a must do in Tokyo. Possibly one of the best things you can do. Highly recommend this.

Cool experience, and the matches are so exciting! . The whole ordeal was interesting; seeing the people in the venue experiencing a traditional sport, the entrance ceremonies of the fighters, and so on... Not to forget the fights themselves !Of course they are over so fast (each 2 competitors face of only once, and most all of the fights are over within no more than 10 seconds or less), and then you wait 4 minutes until the next one..NOTE: English commentary is available via a local radio station . get a receiver for a small charge (before they run out of them) or just bring one with you!

Nice visit . We happened to be in Tokyo the same time the sumo tournament was on and decided to go.We arrived around 2pm and saw all the general admission tickets had been sold out so we had to buy chair seats. They cost us 5000¥ each and we were seated up the top in the back of the stadium.You could still see easily down to the arena. The professional sumos started around 2:45. It really only goes for a few seconds before one person is pushed out of the ring.It was still very cool and we would recommend going to anyone who happens to be in Tokyo at the same time.

Must See. Went to Tokyo for vacation and we happen to goin the middle of a 15 day match for sumo wrestling in Tokyo. Idefinitely recommend going. It's easily understood but recommend getting with a group and guide to hear more history and stories about the wrestlers.

Fantastic if you can see a Sumo wresting day!. I do really recommend a visit to see maybe the worlds oldest sport. I have seen tournament on television but nothing beast a tournament in live. This is a must see in Tokyo. Prepare your booking well in advance the best seats are usually sold out a month before the tournament starts. If you are looking for single seats or two seats try to book A1 seats on row 1 if possible. A1 or B1 boxed seats are better but you need to buy four seats on the floor even if you just need on ticket. The A1 seats are a chair far more comfortable since the tournament starts at 08:30 in the morning and ends at 18:00 in the evening!

SUMO!!. If you are in Tokyo during Sumo season, it would be a shame to miss it! We came specifically for Sumo season, and it did not disappoint. The Ryogoku is a great building, we had class B seats, and they were surprisingly good. Would try to avoid class C, they were wayyy up there. Go to watch the Sumo wrestlers enter the arena around 130pm, before the higher up matches began (around 2)Really exciting, do not miss !

A great experience and fun to watch. Went to watch with my siblings and we had a great time. It is our first time watching sumo wrestling and even though we were seated way up the arena the view was still okay. There are train stations near the arena and there are lots of signs pointing to the right direction so you won't get lost. The matches are very short but exciting. Usually the time it takes for the wrestlers to get ready is much longer than the match itself. Matches from the higher division of wrestlers are more exciting than the ones at the start.

Colourful and Great Fun!. I try to plan my visits to Japan to coincide with a Sumo Tournament. I then work my itinerary around attending towards the end of the Tournament schedule. It is well worth it for the theatricality and great atmosphere. I don't spend all day there but arrive around 3pm, in plenty of time to watch Rikishi arriving and leaving the venue and be seated for the spectacularly colorful entrance parade of the Makuuchi Rikishi and the Ceremonial Entrance of the Yokozuna Champion. I always stay for the 6pm Bow Twirling Ceremony which closes the program. There are many opportunities to see wrestlers in the streets around the venue, arriving, leaving after their bouts and some eating in nearby restaurants. I have found that many of those in the lower divisions are very willing to pose for photos.

Meet a wrestler & go to the museum for free!!. We were a bit unlucky turning up here as there were no events on the days we were in Tokyo, however we still had a great experience as we met a few sumo wrestlers.We'd seen numerous sites advertising the chance to watch wrestlers train, advertising the matches, photo opportunities with them etc, however we just came here to visit the musuem, and realised we could see them here for free!We went around the museum, which isn't very big, and took a few novel pictures outside, and then a few sumo wrestlers strolled in (I presume to train or sign contracts or something!), so although we didn't see a match we still got a few pics, which we never would've got amongst the crowds for any bout.A great experience that would've been a letdown with no sumo wrestlers around!!

Oh Sumo!. One of the very few places to see anything Sumo related.Good bits- impressive sumo stadium from the outside.- check out the museum to understand sumo past and present.- if lucky watch Sumo wrestling- good place to take some fun photos- get some sumo souvenirsBad bits- Museum closed on Sundays.- Strangely Museum shop is closed on Mondays- there is only so much Sumo wrestling one can tolerate, so it can get a bit old after an hour if watching matches.

Really fun and rare experience!. By far a must if you are lucky to be in Tokyo when the Sumo tournaments are. If you go on a day when the tournament just have started you can easily get tickets. If you want to see the finals you better buy in advance. We were there during the beginning of the tournament but had really fun. It is like an American Baseball match where you can sit and relax for a while and every now and then something happen. Grab a beer, sit back and enjoy the big masters challenge each other. This is a must!

An impressive sight into the Sumo tradition.. I booked my tickets several months in advance as I heard they sell out quickly. I managed to find the place easily enough and found my seat. (There was a lot of spare seats near me). I went on my own and thoroughly enjoyed myself although people who had friends seemed to be having a better time. Was amazing to see traditional sumo wrestling and it was a highlight of my trip.

Sumo experience was great, but get there early for English radio. My husband and I went to the January 2015 finals. The sumo wrestling was great and we enjoyed watching it partly through a pair of binoculars that we brought with us. The athleticism of the wrestlers was amazing. We were disappointed that the radios were no longer available when we arrived (around 3 pm). However, I am not sure that we would have wanted to be there for longer as we arrived just around when the more exciting matches were meant to start and we felt like we were able to watch a good number of matches. We pre-ordered tickets through Sumotickets online.The atmosphere during the final matches was great!

A great insight and taste of the great Japanese tradition of Sumo.. I visited this building as it's where the Grand Tournaments of Sumo held. Sadly there was no Sumo event scheduled for while I was in Tokyo but I wanted to see the building anyway and they have a small Sumo museum which is free to enter and had some nice Sumo related exhibits such as the "keshō-mawashi" that the Sumo wear during the ring entering ceremony. There were also photographs of famous Sumo wrestlers and you can buy a booklet that explains all about the Sumo tradition, ranking and rules for a very reasonable JPY100 (that's GB£0.60)!There are some nice paintings of Sumo on the outside of the Kokugikan. You only need about 1/2 an hour here but it's well worth it and gives an insight and taste of the great tradition of Sumo.

An incredible experience!. We attended the semi finals of the January 2015 Sumo tournament. We listened to the English commentary with headsets which was extremely helpful. We loved the whole exciting experience and felt honored to be there as it was the first sell out sumo tournament in 18 years! And we saw a world record broken by one of the fighters, amazing! A must do in Tokyo.

Sumo wrestling. We attended the sumo wrestling grand final and thoroughly enjoyed it especially if you have boys. These guys are real athletes even though they mightn't look it! It was intense and the final fight between the champs was fantastic. It did get a bit long at times so would suggest not an all afternoon event and it's worthwhile getting some back ground on the ceremony. The ear phone and radio had sold out by the time we arrived so that was disappointing. But overall this was one of our highlights of our visit to tokyo.
A must!. Any trip to Japan is not complete with this enthralling and updating experience. Tickets can be hard to come by depending upon circumstances, so we used JTB tours to secure tickets.

Sumo fan for life now. Amazing day. I urge you if your travelling to japan to time it with a sumo tournament. The atmosphere is spectacular and the sport so exciting and complex. Fantastic experience, could not recommended it more. Also use buysumotickets.com, great service

One of the highlights. This was one of the highlights of the trip. I didn't know what I was in for but really enjoyed the whole afternoon. We brought the cheap seats and ended up sitting closer to the action as the stadium was not full, so that's a good tip and also hire a radio for one dollar to listen to the English commendations which was insightful.

Great sumo experience. This was our second trip to the sumo having bought our tickets through Sumotickets online (jeff), the tickets arrived just before Christmas allowing them to be christmas presents.This time we had front row upper seats which was better than our previous mat box on the lower level.The view from the upper seats was better than down below on the more expensive floor area. But we were front row against the rails with no one in front of us.Whisky highball and tayaki , what better way to spend and afternoon with the family. At the end of the night don't rush to the station with the many thousands of others, just have dinner in one of the many good little eateries and wait for the massive crowds at the station to abate.

Really fun. Very glad I did this. Great time. Better to arrive around 2-3pm and just see the better guys though. Arrive too early and maybe you won't have the same enthusiasm for the best matches. Catch a late lunch and then head over. Good there isn't much to behold.

Amazing atmosphere!. My friend and I did this on our first night in Japan and it was amazing. We bought tickets through www.buysumotickets.com as we don't speak Japanese and the guy Jeff, was really great. He put us on a wait list and managed to not only get us last minute tickets but also had them waiting for us at our hotel when we arrived.The sumo tournament itself was amazing to watch, and the atmosphere with all the locala cheering on their favourites was amazing. We even saw the emperor and his wife watching from their box.Absolutley recommend this experience to anyone travelling to Japan during a tournament season.

Always Amazing!. I love sumo! It's such an amazing, fast paced sport! This is my third time at Kokugikan Stadium and every time is as exciting as ever! We usually buy box seating which is very close to the center stage. They are on the expensive side and they are supposed to seat four people. But if you are tall, I would recommend a max of three adults per box. This last time, the boxes next to us had four tall adults and they looked miserable! Since you seat on the floor, you have to keep your knees bent at all times and it becomes very uncomfortable after a while. Also, if you are going to see sumo for the first time (for the experience of being in Japan), you should buy less expensive seats. It's not worth spending a lot of money to be bored and in pain. On the other hand, being at Kokugikan is very exciting, and rooting for your favorite wrestler is a lot of fun!
I'm a SUMO CONVERT. i love SUMO ... THIS IS GREAT - check before you go and if it's on YOU MUST GO .... Especially from 2pm to 6pm

Great atmosphere, insight into the rituals. It was my first time to see a sumo match, and I found it so fascinating to see the BIG men, how they warm up, their costumes, sponsors/advertising introducing them before they walk on. I was on second level but the atmosphere is still great. If you can get seats in lower levels, you are one lucky person :)

Unique Japanese experience. We visited here on the third day of the tournament in Tokyo, January 2015. As overseas visitors we had considered buying the tickets from an agent. However, in the end, given it was early in the competition, we decided to wait until we were in Japan. We bought our tickets from one of the many Seven Elevens (you can also buy them from other supermarkets as well but if you don't speak Japanese, you will need the help of someone who does to enter your ticket requests into the machine). As for the Sumo, it is pure theatre! We arrived at about 1.30 and the time flew by until it was time to go at 6.00. Our only slight criticism was about the English commentary of the event. We rented the radios for a very reasonable price of 100 yen each, once your 2,000 deposit is returned). However, although we obtained the radio at 2.30 (the earliest you can get one) the commentary didn't start until 4.00 and then what you are listening to is the television coverage (rather than coverage that is aimed for the radio). Also if were to do it again, we would bring our own headphones, as we found the ones provided (they sit in the ear) to be a bit uncomfortable after a few hours). But overall, a great experience, one not to be missed.

Sumo is a MUST SEE. Try and time your visit to Tokyo to attend a Sumo tournament. Our day was a highlight of our trip to Japan. We bought our tickets online through www.buysumotickets.com and the service was fantastic. Staff at the stadium were very helpful and they have a special service tent for English speakers.

Sumo Time!. Went her for the tournament at the end of September, we didn't really know what to expect as we always set out to try and watch a sumo match/tournament went coming to Japan.We ordered our tickets before (would strongly recommend doing this from a website) they cam within plenty of time before we left England.Got in with the tickets very easily, we also rented a radio that gave English commentary on the matches. Definetely worth it if you want to know abit of history of sumo from the commentators.The tournament was around 3 hours and got a lot busier during the latter stages of the competition! superb atmosphere for the final!!

Top Experience in Tokyo!. Through our hotel concierge my daughter and I learned there was a Sumo tournament while we were in Tokyo so on a whim we decided to go. We couldn't buy tickets in advance since we were going the same day. So we went over to the stadium, stood in line and bought the cheapest tickets for a certain segment of the tournament. Though we were sitting up high in the stadium, we could see very well, we were among locals and we found the Sumo fascinating. We thought we would stay for a couple of matches but instead stayed for the full 4 hours.

Went at the wrong time. Well it's different, but only saw the shop & small museum. The shrine outside was worth a pic & there is a chance to put your face onto a sumo cut out, if that is what turns you on.

Amazing feats. We booked a tour with Viator, exactly the same as one of the previous reviews but back in late May. Very fortunate to have randomly chosen the day of the semi finals. Our guide was a lovely lady with the most sunny & positive personality. She explained details that otherwise would have been completely lost on us, from the history of sumo, to the rituals, rankings & rules. Radios playing english audio also helped but we didnt actually rely on them as much as I thought we would. We booked the tour as a purely 'touristy' experience & had no real prior knowledge of the sport. Despite this we were completely swept up by the excitement of the crowd and the amazing display of strength, strategy & seemingly impossible agility by the sumo. The crowd enthusiasm was infectious, especially knowing that Japan had not had a yokozuna (grand champion) in some years, so one of the sumos had become a fan favourite as he was Japan's best chance at claiming the title. The bouts are quite short so you don't really have time to get bored (being a non sporty person, I thought that might be an issue). There are also roving beer & pizza sellers that roam the stands, which saves you from having to leave your seat. Souvenir stalls provide plentiful options. While not cheap I did not come across similar sumo themed souvenirs in our travels so was glad to pick up an item while we were there. Surprisingly it turned out being one of the highlights of our trip and I'm very glad that we ended up going!

Big men doing powerful things - go sumo. Got tickets with a days notice from tourist information for $35 each and were advised to go to the tournament at 2.30pm- the event concludes at 6pm each day. The grand tournaments go for 2 weeks, and your ticket allows you to go from 9am, but the big men only come on from 2.30pm.The prefight rituals are just as big as the actual wrestling, great afternoon.Venue is easy to get to and an easy walk.

Sumo different. We spent the whole day at the sumo stadium arriving at 9.30am and leaving when it finished. When we first arrived not so many people there but my the end the whole stadium was full. Different sport and hard to understand exactly with only english as our language but was interesting to watch.

Amazing Cultural Experience. The Sumo Wrestling is one of the best experiences in Tokyo and provides an amazing cultural insight. You have to buy tickets in advance as this event sells out quickly. We sat in the first upper level block and had a good view with reasonably priced tickets. The sumo only runs tournaments at certain times of the year in different cities, I believe in Tokyo it's March/April and September.

Lots of Fun. We bought Sumo tickets for the recent Basho in Tokyo. There is an English website that allows online purchases of tickets about 5 weeks before the event. You print out your tickets at the entrance. You will need your order number from the Email and the credit card used. We bought Section A seats which are about 3800 yen each. These seats are very good and you get a "regular" seat and not have to sit on the floor. The matches are a lot of fun. We arrived at approx. 2pm and watched the highest ranking Sumos walk in the stadium. The top divisions start their matches at about 4pm and will finish at 6pm. Great cultural event ...

An amazing experience I will never forget!. We planned our trip date to Tokyo so we would be there during the Sumo tournament. Me and my husband didn't know that much about sumo wresting but thought it would be an amazing experience and it surely did not disappoint. We booked box C tickets which can fit 4 people but that would be quite a squeeze, it was perfect for the 2 of us as we were able to put our legs out and the view was really good. Tickets do sell out quite quickly so make sure you book in advance. We arrived at about 13.30 and watched some the Sumo wrestlers arrive from outside- they are seen as big celebrities in Japan. At the beginning the stadium was quite empty as it began with the low ranking matches but it helped us get a good idea of the concept. The stadium begins to fill up more when the higher ranked matches begin. Even though all the commentary is in Japanese it is easy to pick up the concept of it all. The atmosphere is great and the fans get really passionate. We bought in our own snacks with us however you can buy bento boxes there too. If you are not in Tokyo during the sumo tournament I would highly recommend seeing the sumo wrestlers in training!

You don't have to be a Sumo fan to have fun here!. Had a fun morning at Sumo when I visited Tokyo in September, access is quite convenient through the metro, the arena was vast and mostly empty and I didn’t know any of the sumos who were battling or pretty much any knowledge about the sport but I still had a fun and entertaining time watching them duke it out, you’re allowed to buy snacks on the premises and bring them with you while you’re watching. It was nice seeing the Japanese audience interactions before fights begin, I didn’t understand what was being said but you sort of get the idea. The sumos in general are treated like celebrities with hordes of groupies waiting and stalking them, it was surreal! There are betting stands as well but you’ll need a strong command of the Language to manage your way through that or a guide. The stadium grounds are not really that big but they are colourful with lots of wall portraits. There were some great souvenir stands around the arena .  I Could have easily spent four to six hours here but I gave it 2 and half hours (sort of got repetitive) and decided to head to the superior Edo-Tokyo Museum (literally next door and a must see!) Sumo is seasonal so plan and book for tickets ahead because they sell out quite quickly especially during the finals, best way to purchase them is through their official website, http://sumo.pia.jp/en/The ticket prices depends on your seating, I got the least expensive arena seats (Y 2000 + a 1000 service charge) on the second floor, didn’t have a problem viewing the action and well worth a visit. Upon completion of the purchase an invoice will be sent to your email address, during match day you’ve got to bring a print out of the invoice and use a special automated kiosk to the right of the ticket stands and exchange them for tickets ( be sure to bring the same credit card you used to purchase the tickets online).

Excellent atmosphere!. We were in Tokyo during the Sumo Tournament and I booked tickets for the penultimate day. I am so glad we went. I booked a box seat for four which was great for two of us, four could have been a squeeze... Great views and an amazing experience! We arrived at around 4pm to watch the main fights, although I wish we had visited all day. The atmosphere was incredible, the cheers, screams, shouts. I'm not particularly a sports fan back home but I really got into this! A memory that will stay with me for life. Do not miss out!

Great experience. We were lucky to be in Tokyo during the National Sumo Tournament in September. I got the tickets online at http://www.sumo.pia.jp/en/. I bought a box seat for 4 people. It's a great experience if you want to know and understand more about the japanese culture. The stadium was completely full and the japanese cheer for their wrestlers. It's an very traditional event. I really enjoy this experience.

Sensational Sumos. We were fortunate to be visiting Tokyo in September while the sumo wrestling tournament was on. Prior to leaving for Japan we booked a sumo wrestling tour using Viator. The tour was conducted by Sunrise Tours (JTB). We were picked up at a hotel and taken to a bus station to meet other tour participants and our guide. To reach Kokugikan Stadium the tour group travelled by train. Our guide showed us through the stadium and found a sumo wrestler who agreed to be photographed with us.Our seats were quite high in the stadium but views of the ring were clear. We received headsets to hear an English commentary of the matches and our guide was seated nearby.The wrestling bouts were amazing. Lots of dramatic pre-fight preparation preceded each bout, but the atmosphere was electric with the crowd cheering for their sumo heroes.At the end of the tournament our guide provided advice on how to return to our hotel, which was easy to do.Overall the tour lasted about 4 1/2 hours but was a fantastic cultural adventure.If you are in Japan when a tournament is in progress, make sure you book tickets to experience sumo wrestling!

Experience a fascinating sport. This is where the big guys show their stuff. It's worth it for the experience to see this ancient sport with all its wonderful rituals and traditions. Tournaments are held several times a year. From the preliminary rounds to the finals takes a couple of weeks or so. It doesn't matter if you're not familiar with the personalities - just go for the experience. Tournaments are held at the Kokugikan Sumo Stadium which is about an easy 10 minute walk from the Ryogoku metro station (Oedo line). Get the general seating tickets which go on sale in the morning for bouts to be held the same day. They cost only 2200 yen but you have to sit at the very back up near the rafters. But you'll still get a decent view and a good feel for the atmosphere.

Sumo is Amazing. One of the primary reasons we went to Tokyo in September was to see Sumo at the Kokugikan. Our tickets were group B, but were near the center of the row and section. They were fantastic. We went for the young sumo wrestlers and stayed all day until the end of that day's bouts. Well worth the money and time spent.In addition to the sumo, there are various places to get food and souvenirs. The takoyaki was very undercooked but the yakitori was good. If you go to the south entrance at the right time, you can see the sumo wrestlers enter the stadium. If you speak Japanese, try using one of the families that provide souvenir and food/beverage services to sumo goers. You do not necessarily need to register in advance with them, but it may be worth it to do so.

A very worthwhile Japanese experience !. I arrived at 2pm explored the stadium and went to the museum and was seated in B arena which to my surprise had a lot of leg room even by western standards and offered a good view,but if I had to do it again I would upgrade to A arena.I rented a radio which offered English commentary and it was fun to sit among the Japanese and hear them cheer on their favorite wrestler. This was a first time experience for me and I got to see two Grand Champions "Kakuryu" and "Hakuho" in separate matches and was an experience I will never forget. After the matches it was nice to see everyone take their trash with them and deposit it into recepticals outside the arena,I wish the fans did that where I come from. Overall it was a great Japanese experience and would do it again in a heartbeat !

Fantastic experience. I am an avid sumo follower and this is the second time for me to watch the sumo. The first time was in Sapporo for an exhibition match. This was the first time for me to watch a tournament. I sat down in hand with a beer and watched sumo for 3 hours. Best 3 hours I had in Tokyo.

One of the best things we did in Tokyo. We were fortunate enough to visit Tokyo during one of the sumo tournaments. I purchased our tickets online before arriving. Only because I wanted to be sure we could get one of the few special box seats they sold which typically seats four, but were sold to seat only two instead. You don't pay as much as buying the four individual seats, but it is higher than just buying two. This also allowed us to have room to spread out, which was really nice. I know that the seats in the upper area (more stadium style) are cheaper, and probably would have been fine, but I found it totally worth the price to be down closer, sitting in the "typical" boxes. We also rented the radios they have so you can listen to the English broadcast of the later "main" matches. We rented two, but found that they actually interfered with each other, so we only used one and just shared the earbuds. Definitely made the experience richer, to understand who the fighters were, what their records were, who the fan favorites were, etc. Definitely check this place out if you visit during tournament time!

Wonderful experience. We were lucky to find the tournament during May. For scheduling, please see this: http://www.sumo.or.jp/en/ticket/year_scheduleThe tournament is a whole day event, having fights since 8am until late afternoon. In the morning the place is almost empty and the fights are good but low ranking fighters. I heard later in the afternoon the place is very crowded and is like a party.Regarding the tickets, you can get them online or at the venue site. We got them there early morning, the cheapest ones. We got inside, enjoy for about an hour and leave. You can reentry one time. Personally it was an excellent experience and good enough time.

Brilliant experience. We booked seats for the May sumo tournament through sunrise tours about 1 month in advance. The tickets for the tournament were only 5100yen and well worth it. There were around 20 bouts but the build up and audience participation makes it really exciting and entertaining. There were pocket radios to use for commentary in English. They have beer and popcorn for sale as well as the usual sporting event/concert snacks. One of the highlights of our trip to Japan and something I would definitely go and see again.

Must see if a tournament is on. I was fortunate to be in town when the May tournament was on, (it's also held in January and September). Seeing a sumo match was one of the best things I did in Tokyo. I've split my review into the event and then tickets, seating and getting there. 1) I arrived at 2.30 although you can get there for 8am but the morning is for low ranked wrestlers. If you do go early you are allowed to leave and re-enter, so you could go visit the Edo museum next door or grab lunch as there weren't many decent eating options (or bring your own food). On arrival I first rented an English audio guide for 100 Yen with 2000 Yen deposit. Before getting to my seat I waited in the side alley where the wrestlers enter the stadium and are applauded by the awaiting fans. It also allows a good photo opportunity close up. At 4 PM the top ranked wrestlers enter the arena and are introduced to the crowd. It was a good atmosphere especially for the later bouts and I found it really interesting with the pre fight rituals and subtle psyching out. The final bout was about 6 PM and rounded off a great experience. 2) I bought my tickets online at buysumotickets.com about a week before the event and had them delivered to my hotel. If ordering early they also ship to your home address. A really good efficient service from them for a small handling fee. In terms of the seats you can have "Box" or "Arena" seats, with box being Japanese style mats which you sit cross legged on and are for groups up to 6 people. Box seats are the lower level. I went for an Arena seat which is upper tier and are normal western style chairs. Cat A is the first 6 rows, Cat B are rows 7-11 and Cat C is 13-15. I went for Cat B which still provided a good view and had sufficient leg room but in hindsight I would have paid more and got the Cat A which are closer and more "comfy" as this is a one off experience. To get to the stadium go to Ryogoku (E12) station on the metro and take exit 3. The stadium is directly behind the Edo museum. In summary a classic Japanese experience that should not be missed. Enjoy!

Sumo is Definitely Worth It!. Even if you are not a fan of wrestling or sumo, I would definitely recommend watching a sumo match if you are in Japan during a sumo tournament and are able to get tickets. Attending a sumo tournament is a very unique and fun experience full of tradition. Some tips:Sumo matches in Tokyo only take place for two weeks in January, May and September.Can purchase tickets online from abroad. We purchased them from the official website.Purchase tickets early, especially for weekend matches or if want to sit near the front.There are 2 types of seats –arena chair seats and floor seats where you sit on a cushion. All seats in the stadium offer a good view though.While the tournament runs from 8am to 6pm you are able to enter any time-most people show up after 2pm but if you want to take pictures or sit in a better seat get there early.For more tips and advice about how to book tickets, where to sit, when to arrive and more, check out http://www.thetravelsisters.com/tips-for-watching-sumo-in-japan/.Sumo was one of my favorite experiences in Tokyo.

Sumo Tournament!!!. A must do/visit when you have the opportunity, as the tournament in Kokugikan Sumo Stadium only happen on January, May and September.Advance ticket purchase are required, I purchased my ticket thru "http://sumo.pia.jp/en/", its very convenient as its accept oversea credit card.We booked our sits on 2nd floor, eventually turn out quite a good view. It was fantastic, unique and one of its kind. Intermediate match start at 2.30pm, Pro match start at 4.00pm and its end at 6.00pm.Make sure you stay until the very end, as they will having a closing ceremony, something like Sumo Dance!!!

Top Entertainment. Went to the May tournament in Tokyo. Great entertainment and atmosphere. Highly recommended although don't sit on the mats too close to the action. In the final bout of the night a wrestler was hurled out of the ring and landed on an elderly gentleman at ringside. Seemed to be seriously injured and was receiving medical attention as we left the arena.

Sumo tournament. We booked a sumo tournament tour through sunrise tours (jtb). It was fantastic. We met at the bus terminal then the guide took us on the train to the stadium. Everything was perfect. We got a radio at 4pm which is in time for the senior matches with English commentary. It finished at 6pm and we made our way back to our hotel on our own.

Brilliant Entertainment . Completely unique, amazing sporting experience!! We enjoyed every minute of this. We were seated on the 2nd floor, one row back from the balcony. We had a fantastic view. We arrived halfway through the lower tier sumo bouts. The bouts were frenetic and the time between the bouts was only a matter of minutes. The main sumo wrestlers were paraded in after the lower tier bouts were finished. This was fantastic. The athleticism of these big men was amazing.I would highly recommend sumo to anyone travelling to Japan. It is only on 6 times a year & 3 of these are in Tokyo. Definitely book before you go!!! Our tickets cost approx 50STG and were worth much more.

Fantastic tournament. The Sumo seasons are very specific depending on which city you are in. but you can find information relating to the tournaments on many internet sites. We went to the Kokugikan to watch the current tournament and this was very easy to do on our own. We bought the tickets from our local 7 - 11 convenience store. The staff in there were very helpful and talked us through which buttons to press to get our tickets. One word of warning - there are primarily two types of seats. "Boxes with cushions" which are nearer the ring but involves sitting on your knees/cross legged for the entire duration - not easy for us Westerners. Or proper theatre type seats - the more you pay the bigger the seat - more legroom etc. That said, everywhere affords a great view. Whilst the tournament runs from 8am through to 6pm the best time to get there is probably around 1.30pm. This will give you time to go to the South Gate to see the Sumo wrestlers arrive. There are cheers and applause as the big stars walk in. Then take your seat for the opening ceremony & matches of the middle ranked players at around 14.20. The same for the big boys starts at around 15.45. There is some excellent pamphlets in English to help you with understanding Sumo plus a small museum. There are places to buy food & drink but we took in our own picnic no problem. If you cannot visit during a tournament we're told you can go in to look around and just next door is the Edo-Tokyo museum. Not entirely sure we understood the rules nor who was the winner, but this experience was absolutely fantastic and a great way to enjoy the essence of Japan
Sumo matches only during season . Sumo matches only happen during Sumo season. The rest of the time this is a museum, open 10-4 daily. The next sumo season is May 11-25.

Great entertainment!. Having this being our first time to Japan we just had to see sumo wrestling. We watched a retirement ceremony event. It had lots of wrestling before and after of course.It was packed full of people standing outside the gates just before the doors opened. You could watch the sumo wrestlers walk along the streets to the stadium which I thought was pretty cool. Many people were taking photos of them. When you get inside, the wrestlers are all standing in the lobby so you can take a picture WITH them as well.We sat in the Arena B section and it was still a very good view. If you want good pictures, bring a telephoto lense. All seats in the arena provide a good view from the 2nd floor. The fights were pretty quick for each round. The later fights were much more entertaining and lasted a lot longer than the earlier fights (higher ranked wrestlers compete later in the event). You can bring your own food in, but there is food to purchase inside as well. Lots of food was sold out about 2/3 into the event, so you might want to purchase early. There is a takoyaki stand inside as well.Location is near the Edo museum which is good because you could do both in one day. We spent our morning/afternoon until about 3-4 pm (when the event ended) at the sumo stadium and then went to to Edo museum for about 2 hours. It was sufficient time.
Interesting.... Interesting experience, this is worth a short visit if you are a general tourist but enthusiasts can spend more time appreciating the finer details. Worth a visit.

Grand Sumo Tournament January 2014, Tokyo. I purchased tickets in advance thru buysumotickets.com (good website) and requested the very first row in the arena 'A' seating for the January 16th match and got a great seat, right on the edge of the balcony, and a chair back instead of a cushion to sit on. I arrived at 9:30 am and watched some of the apprentice matches till about 11:30. Hardly anyone was there so I was able to wander around the arena and take some photos. I decided to leave and go to the Tsujiki fish market for lunch. You are allowed to leave and return once a day, and I had an enjoyable meal of high quality sushi. Many places to eat, all priced very reasonably. I headed back to the arena and had no problem getting readmitted to see the afternoon tournaments. Around 2pm the arena became more crowded as the journeymen wrestlers paraded around the ring wearing their aprons and a measurably better exhibition of sumo wrestling began. While no match I saw lasted a full minute, and most only seconds, the outcomes and wrestlers were cheered and applauded from the ever growing crowd.Finally, about 4:30 the masters started, with the parade to the ring in their aprons, posturing, purifying the ring with salt, and a quick rub with a wet washcloth, these guys were ready to go.It was a fun way for me to spend a day in Tokyo, but then, I like Sumo. I'm sure it's not for everybody, but it was fun. If you want to see the best, and have limited time, I'd suggest coming in the afternoon when the better wrestlers are scheduled.

Didn't go in but walked around and took pictures. The whole Ryogoku area is Sumo Town. The main Sumo stables where the sumos train are there, the chanko restaurants where they eat are there and the main stadium where the wrestling occurs is there. I spent a nice morning walking around and taking pictures of the neighborhood.

A Great Spectacle. We were fortunate enough that there was the New Year Sumo Tournament taking place while we were in Tokyo. Our colleagues took us to the Arena to buy tickets as this proved pretty complicated on-line. We were given the option of buying tickets for Y8,000 with a credit card on the first tier quite a few rows back, but then the ticket agent said if we paid cash we could have some tickets that the wrestlers themselves wanted to sell for cash. We took that option, and found ourselves sitting at the front of the 1st tier on lace covered chairs, quite the VIP treatment. The view was amazing, and the tournament itself was very impressive.This is something that you have to do, its very 'old school', but you get the feeling that you are involved in something very special. You had no idea who was fighting who as everything was written in Japanese, we received a sheet of who was fighting who, but had to ask a spectator close by to explain who was who and which fight we were watching, (she spoke zero English), once that was clear we followed quite easily!.The stadium itself is very impressive, its easy to move around, food and drink was easily available, prices were fine, not a rip off like stadiums in Europe or the USA.This is something you should do.

Sumo Tournament with Children and Seat Reviews. First off, let me preface this review about the arena seating. Nearly every seat has an excellent view, because the arena is fairly small. So you don't have to pay top money for box seats or front upper level. I have seen Sumo twice at this stadium and both times have been great experiences.Here is the breakdown, box seats are most expensive and are just mats you sit on and start at approx 10,000 yen per person for the back and then go up in price as you get closer to the ring. No chairs, just the floor and a small mat. Then you have the 2nd level with four different sections, Arena Chairs A, B, C and general admission. Section A has nice movie theater style seats with little trays for food and drinks (about 8500 yen per ticket). Section B has the same seats with no tray (about 5000 yen). Section C has smaller seats and not as cushioned (about 3700 yen).The general admission is the last row and only sold on the day of the tournaments. The whole upper sections has a total of only 18 rows, so the sight difference is not much between front and backs of section.Now if you have kids, i think it is fine to bring any aged child, never that loud in there. My kids enjoyed it in fact. Under age 3 does not need a ticket (but has to sit on lap). There is plenty of legroom for them to "move" around, because we all know it is hard to still still for five or more hours.I would always sit in Arena Chairs B, simply because they are comfortable, lots of leg room, even for American standards, and still great sights for children to see and move around.The food selections are somewhat limited with mostly Japanese foods and things like hot dogs and French fries. However you can leave the tournament once with reentry, so you could eat at one of the many places nearby. In addition, you can bring your own food and drinks into the stadium, which is a plus for people with kids.If you do not want to be there all day, I suggest getting there at around 1330-1400, that's when the pros start and it gets more lively. It all finishes at around 1800 (6pm).For transportation, the train is the best bet as the Ryogoku train station is right next to the stadium. From Hachioji, Tachikawa, Ome, Yokosuka or Fussa areas, it is approximately 55-75 minutes by train, depending on starting point. If you are coming from the Yokohama, Saitama or Chiba areas, it is only about 40-45 mins by train. If you are staying in Shinjuku or Tokyo, it is only 15 mins by train. Driving is not really an option as for there is no parking at or around the stadium.So to review, best seats are Arena Chairs Section B, you can bring children with no issues, and you can bring food inside on your own. And lastly, many of the workers speak English and are very helpful.

Beyond our expectation!. When we purchased our Sumo tickets, we thought we just wanted to have the experience of watching the game since it does not happen every time we visit Tokyo, e.g. Tokyo only has the tournament in January and it goes to other cities in Japan for the rest of the year. However, initially scheduled to watch only for 1-2 hours, we ended up spending almost the entire day in the Sumo Stadium. The Japanese sitting besides us helping us to understand the game better, not the biggest guy would win the game, its all about technique and experience too. I recommend you to watch the game whenever possible during your visit to Japan

Worthwhile experience!. Bought my tickets in December and extended my holiday in Japan just so I could attend the Sumo Wrestling. I knew very little (and still don't know a whole lot) about sumo wrestling but one thing that is definitely striking is the agility of these wrestlers. We settled into our seats from about 2pm and were there til the end (6pm) and I never wanted to leave my seat. It was a unique experience and something I thoroughly enjoyed. There was also some delicious craft beer outside the gates in an old VW Kombi van (pricey but good). That set the appetite for the day and it was a great event, definitely a must see if you're in tokyo during the wrestling times.

Ten stars. From a sumophile, once you go, you'll be in awe of the culture, heritage, sportsmanship, and the physical abilities of the rikishi. I'm one who likes to attend from the first matches in the morning, featuring new wrestlers, to the Yokozuna matches. There is so much to write about sumo, but even if you have a short time for a taste of the action, it is worth the trip. The wrestlers show they are more than heavy guys in loin cloths, they have a spirituality, a respect for their profession (OK, you may have some arguements here), and an agility that is striking. If you can arrange for it, there are stands that sell meals that you can take to your seats. If you purchase a lower level seat, you can sit close to the action until the crowd arrives during the Juryo matches. Many who attend get hooked, and become lifelong sumophiles. Not to be missed!

Tiny Museum. Unfortunately no shows are available anymore to view, but the museum is open for free. It is quite a small place with very few exhibits. Can give a miss if not already in the area! Wish we had the opportunity to see a sumo match! Tickets should always be booked in advance!

A must see in Tokyo. We booked our tickets online before leaving the UK by following the instructions on http://www.sumo.or.jp/en/ticket/index. Tickets were easily collected from the automated ticket machine at the stadium using my credit card. I laughed at the statement on the website, when booking, about the seats by the ring being dangerous as wrestlers can fall on you! They do. You need to be light of foot if your going to sit right by the ring.We bought 2nd floor arena B seats which were western style seats and we had a really good view of the wrestling.This was a great afternoons sport, we saw the last two leagues of wrestling, you can go for the whole day with your ticket but this may be too much if you have limited time in Tokyo. Stadium is only a minutes walk from the tube station, so is easy to find. This is a must do if you are in Tokyo when the tournament is on.

Fantastic !. Just loved it so much !! You spend the afternoon or the whole day watching these semi-gods fighting like the ancient times, and you can drink some good beers and eat all day. I advise the soup that the sumos are eating, delicious ! Worth every penny !

Very nice spectacle, unique. You might expect a wrestle mania like show, but it is not. Every thing is very traditional, they take it very seriously, like a ritual. We liked it a lot. We had a lot of fun, you can get food and drinks there to enjoy; you can even buy a bento box. Suitable for all the family. Every fight last just a few seconds.A must see!

Great experience!. Stopped off in Tokyo to watch this and I'm glad I did. When arriving at the arena you get a program in English (if needed), it's got a walk way around the arena which as toilets sells food and gifts etc.When first seeing the arena the place is huge with 'boxes' on ground floor and seats on the floor above. You can take food and drink into the arena (I had a box) and come and go throughout (toilets/shops). I went in about 1300hrs and the young, mostly inexperienced wrestlers came on (still worth seeing) the top rikishi come on around 1600hrs.If your phones got FM then bring it because English commentary is broadcast on the radio.

Worth it. There happened to be a Sumo Tournament happening while I was in Tokyo so I decided to check it out one afternoon. I stayed for about an hour and a half which I thought was long enough, try and go later on around 3:45 because that's when the better matches are. I am glad I went and I think it was worth the $35 that it cost. Besides when else will you ever see professional Sumo Wrestling live?

I never knew Sumo was so brutal. Before coming here, I was thinking of Sumo as a couple of fat guys pushing each other around. There is so much more to it than that. First of all, the ritual is very culturally cool, with the announcer and referee singing the praises of each fighter and where they are from. The Grand Rikishi parade is cool. And then the actual "wrestling", which is more like fighting. These guys slap the crap out of each other, choke each other out, and throw each other off of the meter-high sumo platform, so that they fall smashing into the audience. see a 400-pound man get launched 10 feet off a platform into the crowd is quite the spectacle. We had several OMG moments. It was awesome, and I loved it.

So Much Fun!. My last trip to Tokyo was mainly to watch a sumo match at the Kokugikan Sumo Stadium. It was an amazing experience! It's cultural, it's tradition, hard work, training, and competition. The wrestlers are so strong, so dedicated, agile, and it was amazing to see them in person. We got tickets before we left the States and we wanted to make it a "sumo day." First we had lunch at Chanko Kirishima Restaurant right across the Sumo stadium (chankonabe is a Japanese stew eaten by the sumo wrestlers). The food was fabulous! I highly recommend this place. Then we headed to the stadium and waited for the sumo wrestlers to walk in. People cheer for their favorite wrestlers, take pictures and wish them good luck. We found our box which was about 15 feet from the ring. It fit four people, but if you are a big person, it would be uncomfortable. You sit on the floor on a thin cushion (cushions that you see people throwing when a high ranking wrestler suffers an upset) and after a few hours, you can definitely feel it. You can also order food and drinks throughout the matches. The best sumo wrestlers come in the end and the matches are fast and exciting! You are never bored. Highly recommend it!

Fun!. A sport where the portly fan feels a real connection to the action. Easy to understand, a fast rotation of action and ceremony so you are never bored, and a great experience of tradition & good sportsmanship. Cheap, comfy seats too.

awesome sumo match. we were lucky to visit Tokyo during one of the few times a year they have sumo matches. I'm not even into sports and this was really cool. The tradition that is ingrained with sumo is amazing. very entertaining and these guys are bad*ss

Great japanese experience. Got some tickets for the 2013 Aki-Basho, 2nd Level, 3rd Row, great seats for about 8.000 Yen.If you're looking for a thing you can ONLY truly xperience in Japan: Visit a Hon-Basho (Sumo-tournament) if you got the chance to do so.The fights may seem a bit boring first, but when the fighters get better and it's heading towards the Yokozuna-fights, you know why you've paid so much entrance money!REALLY worth it, especially on a rainy day, like I did visit.

Must do in Tokyo. My husband made sure we watched a sumo match in Japan. Sumo wrestling happens in Tokyo only 3x a year and we were lucky to visit in May! At first I thought it was boring, but after a while it was really getting interesting to see how the wrestlers fight. There is some drama going on in the ring! You don't have to attend the whole day's matches. Go in the afternoon and stay until the end as the best wrestlers always compete last. The ceremonies were also entertaining. Ask your concierge for more information and to get the tickets for you. No need for a guided tour for this. The stadium is just outside the Metro.

A Must Do In Japan. My wife and I had so much fun watching the wrestlers both in and out of the Stadium. It’s amazing seeing these famous wrestlers just walking around the stadium like everyone else. That just doesn’t happen in the US. We went early in the September tournament in Tokyo and just walked up and bought tickets. My understanding is the later in the tournament the harder it is to get tickets. Our tickets were Box C and I believe on the North side right by the main entrance not far from the main TV camera. I would definitely recommend these seats because it’s not only the best view of the matches, but also all the traditions that surround Sumo.

Worth the visit!. We went to sumo wrestling for the grand championship. Which happens 3 times a year in different ares of Japan. The preparation each wrestler goes thru before they actually wrestle is quite unique. The "wrestle" itself takes a mere seconds. If you get a chance I would suggest going to watch a few matches.

Sumo tournament - definitely do it!. Attending the second-to-last day of the May sumo tournament was the highlight of our stay in Tokyo for our family of four! We bought tickets online in advance while still in the US through buysumotickets.com--the process was easy and we got our first choice day and seats. We chose "A" seats--the front-most section with regular chairs (below that you sit on the floor--closer to the action, but less comfortable). You will pay a premium to buy online, but the tickets sell out fast, so don't wait. The matches go on all day, but the top division bouts occur from 4-6pm. So show up around 3:15-3:30, stand outside and watch the wrestlers arrive at the stadium, then take your seats in time for the 3:45 ceremony. Definitely pick up an English audio set, as there are English-speaking commentators (from 4-6pm only), and you'll be lost without it. Each contender has a match each day for 15 consecutive days, so there are no semis or finals. By the end of the 21 matches during the 2-hour time period (about 5 minutes each, including about 20 seconds of actual wrestling), we understood some of the strategy and terminology. We were lucky enough to be there on the second-to-last day, and saw the two as-yet-undefeated contenders wrestle each other, an awesome (and lengthy) match. Since both still had to wrestle one more match the following day to determine the winner (or whether there would have to be a playoff), we (my husband, two college-age kids, and I) were excited enough to return to our hotel by 4:00 the next day to watch the final round on television. Highly recommend if you are in town for one of the tournaments.

You Have Got to do This!. We had bought tickets on line and started with a tour guide at Hamamatsucho Station, trained it to Ryogokan Station and into the throngs of people heading towards the stadium. Some of the sumo wrestlers were also arriving through the crowds so we had a close-up view. The local fans were there to cheer them on and many were waiting to see their favourites arrive.We went into the stadium and the foyer was buzzing with people. At the end was a showcase with all of the trophies on offer – the Emporers Cup, another huge one looked like the Davis Cup, and others. We went up to the second floor and all found our seats. Really good visibility and lighting. Some of the Juryo bouts were on so we watched those including the slight Czech sumo who was pitted against the largest of the fighters and beat him quickly and easily much to the crowds delight.We slipped out and bought some yakitori and a beer. The guide was a real sumo freak and she had done lots of homework for us. She had a book made up with all of the matched fighters for the day’s bouts with their pictures and stats so we could follow it more closely. Must admit we hogged the book for more that our fair share of the time. Before the Makuuchi bouts (the top group) there was a ceremony where all of the contestants come out into the ring, and another where the two Yokuzunas with their aprons with huge ropes and bows for adornment put on a bit of a theatrical greeting and the crowd loved it, especially the bit where they individually do a sort of moonwalk shuffle thing with their legs spread either side of the two white lines.There was another ceremony for the two new sumos that had been admitted and their supersized painted portraits were unveiled remotely to join the others in the gallery which runs around the very high ceiling to the arena.Radios are available for hire so that you can listen to the NHK commentary in English after 4 pm when the Makuuchi bouts begin.We had watched sumo on TV before in Japan when on holiday and had a few favourites, Kootooshu, Baruto and Hakuho and they just happened to all win on the day.We can recommend going to anyone even if you aren’t that interested in sumo. The spectacle of unique sporting event and the pageantry rooted in the Shinto samurai culture is wonderful.

Sumo Tournament. I ordered & paid for our tickets before I left the UK and the tickets were delivered to our hotel. We were there on the first day of the tournament so the stadium wasn't full at all and it lacked the atmosphere that a full stadium would have but the Sumo and all the traditions was fun to watch. We were on the second level which had proper seats and had a good view. We spent half a day there which was enough for a first-timer. It's easy to get to the stadium - same subway as the Edo-Tokyo Museum, go up the steps to the Museum and down the other side and you are a couple of minutes away from the Sumo Stadium.

Sumo Wrestling A Bucket List Must Do if in Tokyo in May. We were there in May 2013 and the main tournament was on , it was quite busy but getting seats was easy you can buy at the gate, the atmosphere and tradition is amazing and they give you paperwork to read so you understand the rules and the history of Sumo Wrestling.The junior fighters are in the mornings and from approx 3.30pm the senior and proffessional wrestlers are on including the Grand Champions.The inside of the arena is massive and the room is buzzing the Japanese are very passionate about Sumo so dont stand up or walk around if the grand champions are out its very disrespectful.Highly recommended and take your kids they will have a blast its good fun just to be there but the pomp and ceremony of each fight is very educational for people of all ages. Plan to spend several hours there and I would go in the afternoons more actionWe noticed that throughout the day many groups of school kids came in to watch and learn about Sumo.

highlight of our trip. we were lucky to have caught the may sumo tournament in ryogoku. we didn't book online, so we went there early in the morning to line up for tickets. they gave us an English sumo pamphlet and the day's juryo (second tier) and makuuchi (top tier) match schedules.the morning rounds were for the unranked wrestlers, and kokugikan was almost empty. we watched a few matches, then went to odaiba. we came back mid-afternoon (you can re-enter the stadium only once, and you have to keep your ticket) to catch the makuuchi matches. the ring-entering ceremony was nice, as was the entrance of the yokozunas. this was my first time to watch sumo, and I was completely enthralled -- definitely something that shouldn't be missed.any seat you get will be a good seat, because the stadium is not so big, and you get great views of the action even from the farthest row. on the first floor is a small sumo museum, an information desk and some stalls with souvenirs. the second floor also has an info desk, and some food options. I highly recommend the softserve ice cream :) if you want a taste of chanko nabe (sumo wrestlers' stew), proceed to the basement.kokugikan is just outside ryogoku station. during tournament time, many wrestlers use the train to get to stadium, and you may be lucky to share a platform or car with them.

Go see it if you're in Tokyo in JAN, MAY, and SEPT.. The Japanese love their sumo wrestling as the seats on the first level do get booked out way ion advanced especially over the weekends, but if you are in town - do try to spend a few hours of the late afternoon watching the champions wrestle.Doors open at about 8AM and the day starts off with the amateurs wrestling. If you've bought your tickets online via the Oosumo website, you can collect your tickets from 10AM. If you were wondering - "hey, the match starts at 8AM but I'm missing 2 hours of the start !" don't fret because hardly anyone is there exept for the match judges and wrestlers at 8-11 AM. The stadium will start to fill just before the champions start to wrestle which is around 3:45-4PM. Even the NHK English broadcasts of the day's match starts at 4PM. You can rent a little portable radio at the information counter from 2:30PM and costs 100 yen with a fully refundable 2000 yen deposit.Ringside seats are usually sold out way before but if you can - go for the 1st level "B box" seats for two or for four persons for a better view of the action.Getting there is easy as the stadium is close to the JR and subway stations.The only disappointment was the stadium's restaurant on the second level. Although inexpensive, the food tasted pretty bad. So bring your own bento or buy one from the many shops near the entrance to the arena.Although you could buy tickets on the day itself, 1st floor box seats for two usually sell out quickly as the day of the match approaches - so if you're going to watch the event as a pair, do buy your tickets in advance as there aren't many of such seats available. Plebs like me could forget about the ringside seats as they're usually booked out well in advanced by well connected persons.The match becomes increasingly exciting when the arena starts getting packed and the atmosphere more electric as the clock marches towards 6PM. Do be there by 2 PM to witness the crowd of Japanese fans lining the Southern entrance to welcome their favourite elite wrestlers prior to the "ring ceremony" by these same champions. 2:00 PM is the time the locals start turning up, so if you need to do something else in the morning; by all means don't feel that you've missed out on much at all. The match day ends with a "bow ceremony" at 6PM and drumming from the drum tower to exhort the crowd to return again the next time.

Up close and personal with the Big Boys- a 1400 year old tradition!. One of the strongest cultural impressions of Japan is its tradition of Sumo wrestlers. So to actually be at Kokugian Sumo Stadium on the weekend seeing the big boys in action was an almost surreal experience for me. Like many people, I assumed it would be easy to get Sumo tickets but later realised that tournaments only take place in Tokyo 3 times a year so opportunities to see them are limited and require pre-planning.Ticket prices enable you to see a full day of bouts. Doors open at 8am. The earlier bouts starting from 8:30am are for the more junior lower ranked wrestlers so if you are limited for time, I would recommend arriving early afternoon. Different seats are available. Some are in boxes requiring you to sit on a pillow on the floor and others are seated options. What I loved was actually bumping into the sumo wrestlers (rikishi) outside the stadium on their way to the competition, dressed in their yukata robes. Most of them were happy to have their photo taken. Apparently they start arriving from 2pm at the South Gate. There are plenty of snacks and drinks available for purchase at the stadium and some stalls with banners outside the arena which is only a 3 minute walk around the corner from Ryogoku Stadium. The train station has sumo paintings and other sumo material to see as you exit the train.The bouts themselves are actually very short and can last between 3-6 minutes each. There is a lot of posturing, leg thumping, squatting, mouth washing and salt throwing in the lead up to the actual wrestling component- all part of the tradition which makes it enthralling to watch. To win the bout, the rikishi has to have one part of his opponent's body enter outside the circle ring on the clay sumo ring called the Dohyo. It can be as much as a finger tip or toe- so not necessary to push the opponent all the way out of the ring to win- although at times this does happen when you see one competitor pushed off the ring completely. The final bouts are for the very senior rikishi and the champions.Also during the afternoon there are 2 sumo ceremonies where the rikishi enter the ring wearing ceremonial aprons and form a circle on the sumo ring. They go through a short ritual act before leaving in single file. There are some great photo opportunities during these ceremonies! The concluding part of the day is the bow dance where a specially picked rikishi is handed a gold bow and then does an amazing twirling routine.The venue itself is great- viewing is good from most places although I think the bottom level is better. There are plenty of toilet and refreshment and souvenier facilities. There are also really informative booklets available in the foyer in English that explain the tradition, rules and history of sumo that I highly recommend you read before the bouts.The venue has a Museum exhibition room which can be viewed for free by ticket holders. There are plenty of restaurants in the area near the train station for a meal before or after the tournament.

Incredible Sport and Religious Tradition. Sumo tournaments are held in January, May, and September in Tokyo. The Sumida stadium is a short walk from the Ryogoku stations on the JR and Oedo lines. You can get a reserved seat for as little as 3600 yen on the day of a tournament. Just buy it at the gate where there are lots of helpful staff. Ticket numbers include a row, seat, and Chinese character for North, South, East, or West. If you wish you can rent a radio with BBC English language commentary for 100 yen plus a 2000 yen refundable deposit, but the matches are pretty self-explanatory. The highest rank Makuuchi matches start at 3:45 p.m. Buy a beer at one of the stands and sit back to enjoy an incredible Japanese sport with religious overtones. For 250 yen you can indulge in a bowl of chankonabe stew, the meal of champions, at a restaurant near the entrance. Definitely a fine way to spend an afternoon in Tokyo.

Living cultural tradition!. The Sumo matches do not happen until May, but if you are at the Edo-Tokyo museum this stadium is adjacent to the museum. Sumo wrestlers were milling about and I asked one if I could take a photo. He smiled, took out his ear buds, and posed for the photo. What an expected experience!

If a Tournament in town... Go!. We were in luck that in our trip there was a tournament. We had a great time. Food, and drinks are sold (sorry no hot dogs or burgers). It can be a full day event or only a few hours. We opted for the latter. Knowing the schedule we arrived in the afternoon to watch the grand sumo fighters. Early in the day has the light weight sumo fighters. The bigger boys start after 12PM. A lot of history and tradition still exists here. As for seating, if you don't mind sitting on the floor then get the premium box (can seat 4-6). If you prefer traditional chairs, they are available but further from the ring. Normal chair view is fine if you ask me, unless you can seat on the floor (with cushion) for a long time. Ask hotel concierge for help in getting tickets, and see map before buying.

Great Experience. Went to the Sumo stables first, at 7am to see wrestlers practising in ring and learnt the various techniques and some of the finer points of judging. Up very close about 40cms from the nearest wrestler!! We also learnt much about the life of wrestlers as well as training scheduals - very limited space- for visitors maybe 8 in total. Went to the blessing of the stadium by the Shinto priests with all the officials and the main sumo wrestles. It was a fascinating experience and real insite into the National sport and we see it as one of the highlights of our Japanese tour.

Don't miss it!. If you are in Tokyo during one of the three 2-week long sumo tournaments, make sure you go.It is a little expensive but worth every cent. One of the highlights of my trip to Japan and one of the coolest things I've ever seen. BTW my girlfriend and her sister loved it too!

Sumo wrestling a must in Tokyo. This is my 5th visit to Japan in January for skiing. Each time I have been here I have been drawn to watch Sumo on the local TV. it is truly fascinating. I am addicted and as a female I am on my own amongst my friends:) it is rich in tradition and ceremony and gives a great taste of one aspect of the Japanese culture. If you have the chance go and see it "live".Tickets are best purchased on line before you leave. the tickets go on sale approx a month before the Basho ( comp ) starts. There are 4 Basho per year but not all are in Tokyo. the January tournament is always in Tokyo at the Ryogoku Kokugikan ( Sumo stadium ). You can check details at Nihon sumo kyokai website.Unless you are happy to sit on floor cushions for a couple of hours, you are best to get seats on the 2nd floor (2F on map ). Viewing is great from this position. You can hire a radio at the stadium that you can tune into the English commentary or maybe bring your own radio and tune in yourself. The hire is 100 yen with a 2000 Yen deposit.Plan to be seated by 3pm and you will see some of the Juryo division and be there for the ceremony introducing the senior wrestlers Makkuchi division at about 1545. The day will finish at 1800hrs.The stadium is right across the road from Ryogoku station and directly in front of the Tokyo-Edo museum. There is a small Sumo museum in the stadium area.

Sumo Matches is not to be missed!. After getting sumo tickets 1 month in advance we had the chance to watch SUMO at Ryogoku Kokugikan stadium. The best seats on the first level costs around 6000-10.000 yen over, but you can buy cheaper tickets as low as 2000 yen if you don't mind watching from the second level. It was definitely a true japan experience, seating in a box seat, having 'sumo bento', and watching sumo live. The sumos are huge! Love the rituals where they spread salts to purify the ring, and thump their feet to 'scare the demons' away. The matches is more interesting during the evening where the higher ranks sumo fight, especially the 'yokozuna'. I'd say, if you are in Tokyo when the matches are on, then go for it! (January, May and September)

Sumo. Was lucky enough to be in Tokyo when a sumo tournament was on. I purchased tickets from buysumotickets.com before I left the UK. The company where very good and kept me updated until my tickets arrived. It's a full day event but I arrived at around 3pm to see the top Sumo's contest against each other . The opening ceremony began for the Makuuchi at 3.45pm and was very entertaining in itself. The actual bouts sometimes took a bit of time but with the locals screaming and shouting you can't help but get involved.The tickets are quite pricey but for me this was a one off and not to be missed. Well worth the ticket price.

These dudes are big!. What a great afternoon. Tokyo was hit by a blizzard the other day so it could not have been a better day for us to have reserved tickets to the second day of their 2 week tournament. The nearest metro is Ryogoku which is about a 5 to 10 min walk from the stadium. Plenty of small restaurants around the area as the food in the stadium is pretty average with some sushi packs the best option. Your day can commence as early as 10am but we chose to roll up at 1pm when the big boys get into it. I've never been that interested but after seeing the size of these blokes, their explosive power and the way the locals get into it, we had a lot of fun. Imagine a typical die hard footy fan yelling at their favourite player and that's what the locals do. It was pretty cool. Just a tip though, it's not cheap and we booked four seats as we have two teenage boys. The four seats consist of four pillows on the floor in a square sort of caged section that you get to yourself. So if you can't sit on your butt on a pillow for an extended period get the cheap seats up on the mezz level. Not as good a view but more comfy.

Fun and fascinating. Everything about a sumo tournament at Kokugikan Stadium is great. The gates open at 8am, but don't go that early. All the good bouts are in the afternoon. I've been a couple of times, and these are my hints. Arrive at about 12.30pm. Use the morning to visit the Tokyo Edo Museum (the spectacular building right next door). When you arrive at the stadium, before you go in, spend a little time on the footpath out the front of the stadium to the right. This is the route that many of the Sumo wrestlers take to walk to the stadium from their sumo stables. You will probably see sumo groupies on the footpath, and if you do, join them! You can certainly ask to have your photo taken with some of the less "important" sumo wrestlers. (You can tell the important ones by the young sumos following them, carrying their gear. The really important ones have two young sumos to attend to them.) The fans on the street will shout out encouragement to their favourites as they walk past or as they arrive in their cars, and they create quite an atmosphere. After about half an hour go into the stadium and find your seat. In the entrance foyer of the stadium is a brochure stand with excellent brochures in English talking about the stadium and sumo and its history, customs and rules. Take them to read. After you've found your seat, if you haven't eaten, buy a bento box from one of the stands. They sell out quickly. Then go back out to the sumo entrance, inside the stadium grounds. From about 1.30 the big sumo stars start to arrive, and it's fun to watch the fans get very excited, as well as to see how truly "big" these stars are close-up. Get back to your seat by around 2pm, because the first procession of competitors happens between 2 and 2.30. Then enjoy the bouts. As the afternoon progresses so does the level of competition. The most important bouts are right at the end. After you've seen a couple of early bouts, go and have a look at the sumo museum, in the stadium. After the final bout of the day, when everyone else starts to leave, stay so that you can watch the traditional bow dance. If you're lucky enough to be there on the last day of the tournament, stay for the prize giving ceremony - the trophies are so big, you'd have to be a sumo to lift them!When you buy seats, remember that some of the best seats in the house are the worst for foreigners. The seats on the ground floor of the stadium, including the box seats, are simply flat cushions on the floor, with no room to spread out. You have to be capable of sitting cross-legged or folding your legs under you for hours if you have these seats. We got a box the first time we went, and we spent a lot of time standing at the back, in the aisle. Second floor seats are regular chairs.We bought our tickets before we left for Japan at www.buysumotickets.com. They were helpful via email with seat choices and the tickets came within a fortnight. They charge a small commission, but it's worth it to know that you've got a seat. The tournament we attended was sold out weeks in advance.The sumo tournament is a sporting event filled with customs and ceremonies that are hundreds of years old. It is definitely a cultural experience, as well as a sporting event. There's nothing quite like it - the extraordinary physiques of the competitors, the costumes of the officials, the arena, the attendants, the singing announcements, the posturing and gamesmanship, and so many other things unique to sumo. Don't miss it!

The Place to Go For Sumo. Every visitor to Japan should see Sumo once and the Tokyo Kokugikan (a 20 minute cab ride from Tokyo Station) is the best place to see Sumo once. You should check your travel schedule against the Sumo schedule as sumo is only in Tokyo for about 4-6 weeks a year. If you are a business traveller to Tokyo a vist to the Kokugikan is recommended on a spare afternoon or stay-over Saturday or Sunday afternoon. You can get tickets through JTB or your hotel concierge. Take you camera and relax! It is a unique cultural experience.

great experience. I was lucky that when I arrived there was the international grand tournament going on. had to line up really early in the morning to get a ticket for the same day, but it was completely worth it. you need to be informed that the best athletes compete towards the end of the day. its a really nice ritual to go and observe

Quintessential Japanese experience - not to be missed. Japan is a land of immense contrasts, often between the very modern and the very traditional. Sumo is just one expression of this - you can tour hypermodern parts of Tokyo, or museums and galleries, then step into Kokugikan stadium to witness something that seems to be as different as it gets. There are 2 grand sumo tournaments per year. We were lucky enough to be in Tokyo during the autumn one. Getting tickets about halfway through the 20 or so day tournament easy easy. Instead of trying to go early in the morning to get cheaper day tickets (there is a chance that there are none left, plus the interesting fights only start later in the day, so you'd have to trek there twice). So we got regular tickets for a Monday, close to 100 Eur for 2 tickets (we went with a 10 months old baby [who was not perturbed by the fighting at all], who got in for free).It's an amazing experience, even if you don't understand much about sumo. It's just great to see the rituals, people rooting for their favorite starts, and lots of salt tossing and belly slapping. Really not to be missed.
