In the end we stayed some 2 hours and had our fill, but they also have food and drinks, so spending half a day or so there also seems easy enough.

Sumo Sunrise tour. I loved this tour, the Sumo was a thrill, we did get to see what I call the grand final, we had a sensational tour guide "Take" and he explained everything that was going to happen. We had "B" grade level 2 seats, I would recommend to pay for close up seats. Tour gave us English translation radio which explained everything that was going on, Even saw the Prime Minister present the winner trophy.

Sumo wrestling is so awesome!. Loved this stadium! One of the things I was really hoping to check out in Tokyo was sumo wrestling, and I am glad that I got the chance. At around 10:00 am, I went to the stadium to purchase general admission tickets which were 2100 yen. During the morning, there weren't many people watching the fights as the really big fights happen later on in the day (starting at around 2:00 pm). It is still fun to watch them though. I ended up watching some of the fights in the beginning, leaving to grab some lunch, and then coming back and watching some more until around 5:00-5:30 pm. The price is definitely worth it for watching all those sumo fights!You're only allowed one readmission, and you have to get a stamp as you leave, and then re-enter using the side entrance (and showing the stamp).What is really neat, is when you are entering the sumo stadium, a lot of times you will be walking right next to a sumo wrestler on his way in! There are usually people trying to take their photos or shaking their hands. :)Definitely a cool thing to experience!

A beer while watching sumo... what more could you ask for?. We were in Japan during the May 2012 tournament so definitely had to go check sumo. Went on a Friday with the general admission ticket. It was "dead" in the morning, not many people watching the fights and honestly, the pace was slow. We left and came back a few hours later when it was a lot more packed. Since it was a readmission, we had to go in through a separate entrance which was the one the wrestlers take. It was awesome to walk amongst them on the sidewalk while the crowd was cheering. Had a beer while watching sumo because we simply had to. The only thing I didn't really like was that it seemed like there were more tourists than locals. Wouldn't do it again but definitely a worthwhile addition to a trip.

Sumo Wrestling!. This is one spectaculor experience. Such a huge tradition in Japan and the sumo, including the beautiful arena (pretty much all seats are good seats - thanks to buysumotickets.com) is something not to be missed. I surprised my husband, sister and brother in law with tickets - we sat in the "box" seats which is an experience in itself - and were lucky enough to also experience the retirement of a famous sumo which also included the "hair cutting" ceremony. Although sumo is not all year (much like our football, baseball etc - it has its season), if you are lucky enough to be in Japan during this time, it's definitely something to do. For tickets, go to www.BuySumoTickets.com. They (Jeff) were absolutely amazing and went above and beyond to answer all my questions.

Lots of flesh and great experience. Up there with Capsule hotels, Gesihas and Karaoke as the ultimate Japanese experience!Its not every week though as some think, so plan in advance. Simple search will show you schedule and days of tournament, book in advacne as sell out fast on the dayWe booked seats in area B, which were good view and pretty relaxed, couldn't do the tatami mats, so can't say what they are like, price and discomfort put us off!Early fights aren't much but go about 2ish to see Juryo Ring Entering Ceremony and then the Makuuchi (big boys) later!Also worth staying outside the stadium for abit with the crowds to see the sumos walking in, always good seeing one of the bigger boys like Hakuho or one of the Japanese favourites Check out http://vimeo.com/29776934for short video, without showing too much, great soundtrack as well!

Sumo central. Some sumo artifacts on display including a video of historical development. No live demonstrations at time of visit but did run into two in-dress sumo wrestlers on the way out which made up for my disappointment not seeing them practice.

Seeing Sumo. If you have chance to go....GO! We knew we would be in Tokyo in tournament time and arranged our tix before we travelled through JapanBall.com. We purchased the lowest priced tix and still had a great view from the best side of the stadium. It was a great spectacle, and we wished we could have stayed for the evening session, but we had baseball to get to. Our tix did allow for us to stay - they cover your attendance for the whole day....allow a day, if you can...to take in the whole spectacle of the wrestlers arriving at the stadium outside, to the grand stadium entrances, to the amazing displays of one-upmanship and wrestling....all this from a non-sports-fan!

Must See!. If you're in Japan while a tournament is going on, you simply must go. It's a unique, memorable experience. Even if you know very little about sumo, once the matches start you'll be drawn in and you'll end up just as excited as the other spectators around you. The stadium is really easy to find - it can be seen from the JR Ryogoku Station, which is on the Chuo Line. We reserved tickets in the Arena C area ahead of time through BuySumoTickets.com and they delivered them to our hotel in Shibuya so they were there when we arrived. I'm not sure this is always necessary, but we were planning on getting there later in the day instead of early in the morning, so it seemed like a good idea. There were very helpful attendants inside the stadium entrance who helped us find our seats. Our seats were the farthest away from the action that can be reserved in advance, but I could see and hear everything just fine. Try to get a seat on the north or south side of the stadium, as the wrestlers face east and west and this will give you the best view. Your ticket will get you in for a full day - 8 AM to 6 PM. We got there around 3:00,around when the pros started, and found that that was plenty of time. The wrestlers who are the biggest deals go at the end, so just be sure not to miss the later matches.

Great visitor experience!. Spent a day at the winter tournament and was one of the most enjoyable days of our trip. How many folks outside of Japan get to have this experience? Well worth the price to see this unique cultural event. Arrived early and stayed late so we saw all levels of Sumo. Enjoyed waiting outside for arrival of participants and they were all very accommodating with pictures. If your trip corresponds with one of the tournaments, make sure you add it to your itinerary. Would do it again in a heartbeat!

sumo rocks. had a great day yesterday at Sumo in Tokyo. its probably not for everyone as the matches start at 9am and go til 6pm. the later in the day the better the talent. unless you want to sit on your azz for the entire time, get an Arena Seat. and i would gladly buy the best arena seat available. I bought mine from www.japanball.com, and they hand delivered the tickets to me. they charge a $59 premium no matter the number of tickets you buy. it was well worth it. as for sumo, if you like baseball, and have an interest in different cultural endevors, go. it was great fun. got to see the world champion who is mongolian. its great anytime when you see a world's best. go, its good stuff..c

Awesome Practice Session last Apr 29, 2012. While planning for our Tokyo trip, I wanted to witness a Sumo match. Unfortunately, during the time when we were in Tokyo (Apr 27-May1), the season hasn't started yet, but we were lucky that a practice session was held on Apr 29 and it was open for public for free. You can instantly know from the crowd's reactions who are the rikishi favorites during the session. Great experience. Highly recommend watching the actual matches if you are in town. I would, when I come back to Tokyo. :DI saw the prices of the tickets on actual matches, and it would cost a few hundred (and thousand yen for nearer seats). Blogged about my experience here:http://www.tagofabic.com/2012/05/sumo-wrestling-practice-session-in.htmland the official website of Sumo schedules here:http://www.sumo.or.jp/eng/kyokai/event/index.html

Sumo!. I've seen Sumo a couple of times. It's not an everyday thing so I was very fortunate to have had that opprotunity. One tournament is 14 days and only 4 tournaments per year. It's really amazing. Sometimes one match is over in a matter of seconds, sometimes it lasts for a couple of minutes. Either way, once the wrestlers are facing each other ready to "go" you can't take your eyes away!

unusual but fun. I had the opportunity to see some famous sumo wrestlers although I can't remember their names anymore. Great atmosphere the sheer power and appearance of these fighters in their traditional garb was really interesting for me.

Superb Sumo - easy to book yourself. We had an amazing time when we visited The Kokugikan in January 2011 even as none sports fans. We were desperate to see some live sumo action while in Japan and very luckily for us, one of the 6 tournaments taking place in Tokyo each year was in town. We used a website called www.sumo.or.jp - which had easy access information for ticket booking in english. (OK they charged per ticket for processing but who does'nt these days!). You also receive a leaflet containing the history of the art (and more recently sport) which is just fascinating.The site has date of release information and floor plans of all the various venues across the country. The earlier you book, even if taking cheaper tickets, the better the seat. For example we took tier C tickets in Tokyo but were on the front row, paying half what the row in front were, for the same view. If you book via the site you get a confirmation within 3 days which you hand in on arrival. It is also possible to just arrive on the day and pay on the door, though this is less advisable.Inside the stadium are traditional foods, memoribilia and a small museum (though not much in english). But in all honesty you will probably be caught up in the action as soon as you arrive. The ticket gives you entry to the earlier less senior rounds which usually take place late morning, then continuous action until the Yokozuna class in the mid afternoon, finishing around 6pm ish. Dont miss the start of each session when all fighters arrive in the ring together, great for photos! Thoroughly worth it, cannot recommend it highly enough, enjoy!

Worth a visit, wish it was more comprehensive!. The Sumo Museum is a bit tricky to get to from the subway. It's nestled behind the Edo-Tokyo Museum in the front of the Kokugikan building where the matches are held. Once inside the gates you can't miss it, just look for the wall painted with big Sumo wrestlers. The museum itself is free to enter and you are given a complimentary booklet describing the history of the sport. There is adequate (and sometimes charming) English signage but most of the descriptions are obviously in Japanese. There is a wall of past Grand Champions and numerous other artifacts. To the left of the museum as you face the arena is a store selling the requisite momentos. There are only three tournaments a year held here so unless you come during those times there won't be a match to watch.My only problem with the museum was that it was so small! Being that Sumo wrestling is one of the 3 or 4 things most people can even superfically relate to Japan, I was hoping for a more extensive, intereactive experience. How about having real wrestlers there showing their moves or a life size ring and talks on Sumo history, etc. ? You can easily do a comprehensive visit here in 45 minutes.Dont' get me wrong, it's still worth the trip but I just wish there was more to it; still recommended especially for those already going to the Edo-Tokyo museum.
